div.head: THE FIRST ACT

stage.stage: SCENE : The drawing-room at Kenyon-Fulton . It is a handsome apartment with large windows , reaching to the ground . On the walls are old masters whose darkness conceals their artistic insignificance . The furniture is fine and solid . Nothing is very new or smart . The chintzes have a rather pallid Victorian air . The room with its substantial magnificence represents the character of a family rather than the taste of an individual .
It is night and one or two electric lamps are burning .

MOORE , an elderly impressive butler , comes in , followed by GANN . This is CLAUDE INSOLEY ’ S gamekeeper , a short , sturdy man , grizzled , with wild stubborn hair and a fringe of beard round his chin . He wears his Sunday clothes of sombre broadcloth .

sp.speaker: MOORE
sp.p: You ’ re to wait here .

div.stage: GANN , hat in hand , advances to the middle of the room .

sp.speaker: MOORE
sp.p: They ’ ve not got up from dinner yet , but he ’ ll come and see you at once .

sp.speaker: GANN
sp.p: I ’ ll wait .

sp.speaker: MOORE
sp.p: He said I was to tell him the moment you come . What can he be wanting of you at this time of night ?

sp.speaker: GANN
sp.p: Maybe if he wished you to know he ’ d have told you .

sp.speaker: MOORE
sp.p: I don ’ t want to know what don ’ t concern me .

sp.speaker: GANN
sp.p: Pity there ain ’ t more like you .

sp.speaker: MOORE
sp.p: It ’ s the missus ’ birthday to-day .

sp.speaker: GANN
sp.p: Didn ’ t he say you was to tell him the moment I come ?

sp.speaker: MOORE
sp.p: I ’ ve only just took in the dessert . Give ’ em a minute to sample the peaches .

sp.speaker: GANN
sp.p: I thought them was your orders .

sp.speaker: MOORE
sp.p: You ’ re a nice civil-spoken one , you are .

div.stage: With an effort GANN prevents himself from replying . It is as much as he can do to keep his hands off the sleek , obsequious butler . MOORE after a glance at him goes out . The gamekeeper begins to walk up and down the room like a caged beast . In a moment he hears a sound and stops still . He turns his hat round and round in his hands .
CLAUDE INSOLEY comes in . He is a man of thirty-five , rather dried-up , rather precise , neither good-looking nor plain , with a slightly dogmatic , authoritative manner .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Good evening , Gann .

sp.speaker: GANN
sp.p: Good evening , sir .

div.stage: CLAUDE hesitates for a moment ; to conceal a slight embarrassment he lights a cigarette . GANN watches him steadily .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: I suppose you know what I ’ ve sent for you about .

sp.speaker: GANN
sp.p: No , sir .

lg.l: I should have thought you might guess without hurting yourself . The
Rector tells me that your daughter Peggy came back last night .

sp.speaker: GANN
sp.p: Yes , sir .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Bit thick , isn ’ t it ?

sp.speaker: GANN
sp.p: I don ’ t know what you mean , sir .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Oh , that ’ s all rot , Gann . You know perfectly well what I mean . It ’ s a beastly matter for both of us , but it ’ s no good funking it .... You ’ ve been on the estate pretty well all your life , haven ’ t you ?

sp.speaker: GANN
sp.p: It ’ s fifty-four years come next Michaelmas that my father was took on , and I was earning wages here before you was born .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: My governor always said you were the best keeper he ever struck , and hang it all , I haven ’ t had anything to complain about either .

sp.speaker: GANN
sp.p: Thank you , sir .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Anyhow , we shan ’ t make it any better by beating about the bush . It appears that Peggy has got into trouble in London .... I ’ m awfully sorry for you , and all that sort of thing .

sp.speaker: GANN
sp.p: Poor child . She ’ s not to blame .

div.stage: CLAUDE gives a slight shrug of the shoulders .

sp.speaker: GANN
sp.p: I want ’ er to forget all she ’ s gone through . It was a mistake she ever went to London , but she would go . Now I ’ ll keep ’ er beside me . She ’ ll never leave me again till I ’ m put underground .

lg.l: That ’ s all very fine and large , but I ’ m afraid Peggy can ’ t stay on here ,
Gann .

sp.speaker: GANN
sp.p: Why not ?

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: You know the rule of the estate as well as I do . When a girl gets into a mess she has to go .

sp.speaker: GANN
sp.p: It ’ s a wicked rule !

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: You never thought so before , and this isn ’ t the first time you ’ ve seen it applied , by a long chalk .

sp.speaker: GANN
sp.p: The girl went away once and come to grief . She wellnigh killed herself with the shame of it . I ’ m not going to let ’ er out of my sight again .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: I ’ m afraid I can ’ t make an exception in your favour , Gann .

sp.speaker: GANN
sp.p: Desperately .Where ’ s she to go to ?

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Oh , I expect she ’ ll be able to get a job somewhere . Mrs. Insoley ’ ll do all she can .

sp.speaker: GANN
sp.p: It ’ s no good , Squire . I can ’ t let ’ er go . I want ’ er .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: I don ’ t want to be unreasonable . I ’ ll give you a certain amount of time to make arrangements .

sp.speaker: GANN
sp.p: Time ’ s no good to me . I haven ’ t the ’ eart to send her away .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: I ’ m afraid it ’ s not a question of whether you like it or not . You must do as you ’ re told .

sp.speaker: GANN
sp.p: I can ’ t part with her , and there ’ s an end of it .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: You ’ d better go and talk it over with your wife .

sp.speaker: GANN
sp.p: I don ’ t want to talk it over with anyone . I ’ ve made up my mind .

div.stage: CLAUDE is silent for a moment . He looks at GANN thoughtfully .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Deliberately .I ’ ll give you twenty-four hours to think about it .

sp.speaker: GANN
sp.p: Startled .What d ’ you mean by that , sir ?

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: If Peggy isn ’ t gone by that time , I am afraid I shall have to send you away .

sp.speaker: GANN
sp.p: You wouldn ’ t do that , sir ? You couldn ’ t do it , Squire , not after all these years .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: We ’ ll soon see about that , my friend .

sp.speaker: GANN
sp.p: You can ’ t dismiss me for that . I ’ ll have the law of you . I ’ ll sue you for wrongful dismissal .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: You can do what you damned well like ; but if Peggy hasn ’ t gone by to-morrow night I shall turn you off the estate on Tuesday .

sp.speaker: GANN
sp.p: Hoarsely .You wouldn ’ t do it ! You couldn ’ t do it .

div.stage: There is a sound of talking and laughter , and of a general movement as the dining-room door is opened .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: They ’ re just coming in . You ’ d better hook it .

div.stage: MISS VERNON and EDITH LEWIS come in , followed by GRACE . For a moment GANN stands awkwardly , and then leaves the room . MISS VERNON is a slight , faded , rather gaunt woman of thirty-five . Her deliberate manner , her composure , suggest a woman of means and a woman who knows her own mind . EDITH LEWIS is a pretty girl of twenty . GRACE is thirty . She is a beautiful creature with an eager , earnest face and fine eyes . She has a restless manner , and her frequent laughter strikes you as forced . She is always falling from one emotion to another . She uses a slightly satirical note when she speaks to her husband .

lg.l: Oh , what a lovely night ! Do let ’ s go out .
May we ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Of course , if you want to .

sp.speaker: EDITH
sp.p: I ’ m perfectly sick with envy every time I look out of the window . Those lovely old trees !

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I wonder if you ’ d be sick with envy if you looked at nothing else for forty-six weeks in the year ?

sp.speaker: EDITH
sp.p: I adore the country .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: People who habitually live in London generally do .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: Aren ’ t you fond of the country ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Vehemently .I hate it ! I hate it with all my heart and soul .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: My dear Grace , what are you saying ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: It bores me . It bores me stiff . Those endless trees , and those dreary meadows , and those ploughed fields . Oh !

sp.speaker: EDITH
sp.p: I don ’ t think I could ever get tired of the view from your dining-room .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Not if you saw it for three meals a day for ten years ? Oh , my dear , you don ’ t know what that view is like at an early breakfast on a winter ’ s morning . You sit there looking at it , with icy fingers , wondering if your nose is red , while your husband reads morning prayers , because his father read morning prayers before him ; and the sky looks as if it were going to sink down and crush you .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: You can ’ t expect sunshine all the year round , can you ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Smiling .True , O King !

sp.speaker: EDITH
sp.p: Well , I ’ m a Cockney , and I feel inclined to fall down on my very knees and worship those big trees in your park . Oh , what a night !

lg.l: In such a night as this ,
When the sweet wind did gently kiss the trees
And they did make no noise ....

div.stage: MISS VERNON and EDITH LEWIS go out . GRACE is left alone with her husband .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: What on earth was Gann doing here ?

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: I had something to say to him .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: May I know what ?

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: It would only bore you .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: That wouldn ’ t be a new experience .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: I say , you ’ re looking jolly to-night , darling .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: It ’ s kind of you to say so .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Were you pleased with the necklace I gave you this morning ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Smiling .Surely I said so at the time .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: I was rather hoping you ’ d wear it to-night .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: It wouldn ’ t have gone with my frock .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: You might have put it on all the same .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: You see , your example hasn ’ t been lost on me . I ’ ve learnt to put propriety before sentiment .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Rather shyly .I should have thought , if you cared for me , you wouldn ’ t have minded .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Are you reproaching me ?

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: No !

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Only ?

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Hang it all , I can ’ t help wishing sometimes you ’ d seem as if — you were fond of me , don ’ t you know .

lg.l: If you ’ ll point out anything you particularly object to in my behaviour ,
I ’ ll try to change it .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: My dear , I don ’ t want much , do I ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I don ’ t know why you should choose this particular time to make a scene .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Hang it all , I ’ m not making a scene !

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I beg your pardon , I forgot that only women make scenes .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: I only wanted to tell you that I ’ m just about as fond of you as I can stick .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Suddenly touched .After ten years of holy matrimony ?

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: It seems about ten days to me .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Good God , to me it seems a lifetime .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: I say , Grace , what d ’ you mean by that ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Recovering herself .Oughtn ’ t you to go back to the dining-room ? Your brother and Mr. Cobbett will be boring one another .

div.stage: CLAUDE looks at her for a moment , then rises and goes out . GRACE clenches her hands , and an expression of utter wretchedness crosses her face . She passes her hand across her eyes with an impatient gesture , as if she were trying to shake herself free from some torturing thought . MOORE comes in with coffee on a salver .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Put it down on the table .

sp.speaker: MOORE
sp.p: Yes , madam .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Miss Vernon ’ s in the garden with Miss Lewis . Will you tell them that coffee is here ?

sp.speaker: MOORE
sp.p: Very good , ma ’ am .

div.stage: He goes out of one of the French windows into the garden . In a moment MISS VERNON comes in .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Isn ’ t Edith coming ?

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: I sent her to get a wrap . We want to go down to the lake .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Will you have some coffee ?

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: Thank you .... I was trying to remember how long it is since I was here last .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Pouring out the coffee .It was before I was married .

lg.l: I ’ m devoted to Kenyon , I ’ m so glad you asked me to come and spend
Whitsun here .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: My mother-in-law wrote and told us that you weren ’ t engaged .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: With a smile .That sounds rather chilly .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Does it ?

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: Abruptly .May I call you Grace ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Looking up , faintly surprised .Certainly . If you wish it .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: My name is Helen .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Is it ?

div.stage: MISS VERNON gives a slight smile of amusement , then gets up and stands before the fire-place with her hands behind her back .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: I wonder why you dislike me so much ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I don ’ t know why you should think I do .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: You don ’ t take much trouble to hide it , do you ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I ’ m sorry . In future I ’ ll be more careful .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: Rather wistfully .I wanted to be great friends with you .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I ’ m afraid I don ’ t make friends very easily .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: We live so near one another . It seems rather silly that we should only just be on speaking terms .

div.stage: A very short pause .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: They wanted Claude to marry you , didn ’ t they ? And he married me instead .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: When I saw you at your wedding , I couldn ’ t help feeling I ’ d have done just the same in his place .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: With a twinkle in her eye .And now they want you to marry his brother Archibald .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: Smiling .So I understand .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Are you going to ?

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: He hasn ’ t asked me yet .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Five thousand acres in a ring fence . It seems a pity to let it go out of the family .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: It ’ s such a nuisance that a plainish woman of six-and-thirty has to be taken along with it .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Did you ever care for Claude ?

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: If I did or not , I ’ m very anxious to care for his wife .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: Well , partly because I ’ m afraid you ’ re not very happy .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Startled .I ?Almost defiantly .I should have thought I had everything that a woman can want to make her happy . I ’ ve got a husband who adores me . We ’ re rich . We ’ re —with a sudden break in her voice— happy ! I wish to God he had married you ! It ’ s clear enough now that he made a mistake .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: With a chuckle .I don ’ t think it ’ s occurred to him , you know .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: How many times d ’ you suppose his mother has said to Claude : Things would be very different now if you ’ d had the sense to marry Helen Vernon .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: Yes , in that case I must say it ’ s not to be wondered at if you don ’ t like me very much .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Like you ! I hate you with all my heart and soul !

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: Good gracious me , you don ’ t say so ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: With a sudden flash of humour .You don ’ t mind my telling you , do you ?

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: Not a bit , but I should very much like to know why ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Because I ’ ve got an envious disposition and I envy you .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: A solitary old maid like me ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: You ’ ve got everything that I haven ’ t got . D ’ you suppose I ’ ve lived ten years in my husband ’ s family without realising the gulf that separates Miss Vernon of Foley from the very middle-class young woman that Claude Insoley was such a damned fool as to marry ? You ’ ve got money and I haven ’ t a farthing .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: Money isn ’ t everything .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Oh , don ’ t talk such nonsense ! How would you like to be dependent on somebody else for every penny you had ? If I want to get Claude a Christmas present I have to buy it out of his money .... It wouldn ’ t be so maddening if I only had forty pounds a year of my own , but I haven ’ t a penny , not a penny ! And I have to keep accounts . After all , it ’ s his money . If he wants accounts why shouldn ’ t he have them ? I have to write down the cost of every packet of hair-pins .With a sudden chuckle .And the worst of it is , I never could add .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: That , of course , must increase the difficulty of keeping accounts .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I ’ ve been an utter failure from the beginning . They despised me because I was a nobody and not even a rich nobody ; but I was a strapping , healthy sort of young woman and they consoled themselves by thinking I ’ d have children — a milch cow was what they wanted — and I haven ’ t even had children ....

div.stage: MISS VERNON , not knowing what to say , makes a little gesture of perplexity and helplessness . There is a brief pause .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Oh ! I ’ m about fed up with all the humiliations I ’ ve had to endure .

div.stage: EDITH LEWIS comes in with a wrap which she gives to MISS VERNON .

sp.speaker: EDITH
sp.p: Will this do ?

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: Thanks so much . You ’ re a perfect angel .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: You mustn ’ t stay out more than a few minutes . The men will be here in a moment , and I want to play poker . When my mother-in-law comes we shall have to mind our p ’ s and q ’ s .

sp.speaker: EDITH
sp.p: You don ’ t like Mrs. Insoley ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Mrs. Insoley doesn ’ t like me .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: Nonsense ! She ’ s very fond of you indeed .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I could wish she had some pleasanter way of showing it than finding fault with everything I do , everything I say , and everything I wear .

sp.speaker: EDITH
sp.p: She ’ s coming to-morrow , isn ’ t she ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Yes .With a quizzical smile .She ’ ll thoroughly disapprove of you . When I introduce you to her : This is Miss Lewis — she ’ ll look at you for a moment as if you were a kitchen-maid applying for a situation and say : Lewis .

sp.speaker: EDITH
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Because , like myself , you ’ re not county .

sp.speaker: EDITH
sp.p: Oh !

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: It ’ s all very fine to say : Oh ! but you don ’ t know what that means . In London , if you ’ re pretty and amusing and don ’ t give yourself airs , people are quite ready to be nice to you ; but in a place like this , you can have every virtue under the sun , and if you ’ re not county you ’ re of no importance in this world , and you ’ ll certainly be very uncomfortable in the next .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: Smiling .I think you ’ re extremely hard on us . If you have the advantage of ....

lg.stage: Seizing the opportunity which MISS VERNON ’ S hesitation gives her .
lg.l: Middle-class origins ?

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: You needn ’ t grudge us the perfectly harmless delusion that there is a difference between a family that has lived in the same place for three or four centuries , with traditions of good breeding and service to the country — and one that has no roots in the soil .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I seem to hear Claude ’ s very words .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: Good-humouredly .Of course we have our faults .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: You ’ re the first member of your class that I ’ ve ever heard acknowledge it .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: Meditatively .I wonder if you ’ d despise us so much if you had a string of drunken , fox-hunting squires behind you .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Oh , my dear , when I was first married I used to lie awake at night wishing for them with all my heart . When the neighbours came to call on me I could see them obviously lying in wait for the aitches they were expecting me to drop . A Miss Robinson , wasn ’ t she ? Robinson ! Are there people called Robinson ? Oh , how I wanted to scratch their ugly old faces !

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: How lucky I was abroad for so long ! You might have disfigured me for life .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I ’ ve often thought that if the Archangel Gabriel came down in Somersetshire , they ’ d look him out in the “ Landed Gentry ” before they asked him to a shooting-party .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: I don ’ t think you ought to judge us all on Mrs. Insoley . She ’ s a type that ’ s dying out .

sp.speaker: EDITH
sp.p: I don ’ t want to seem inquisitive , but if you don ’ t like Mrs. Insoley why on earth d ’ you have her to stay here ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Simple-minded child ! Because even in a county family money ’ s the only thing in the world that really matters , and we ’ re penniless , while Mrs. Insoley —with a quick , defiant look at MISS VERNON— Mrs. Insoley stinks of it .... Do I shock you ?

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: With a smile .No , because I see you ’ re trying to .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Claude has nothing but the house and land and his principles . And if we ’ re able to have the hounds and the shooting and a couple of cars , it ’ s because Mrs. Insoley pays for it .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: Explaining to EDITH LEWIS .Mrs. Insoley was an heiress .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: She was a Bainbridge , and you ’ ll hear her thank God for it frequently .

div.stage: ARCHIBALD INSOLEY and HENRY COBBETT come in . ARCHIBALD is a pleasant , good-looking man of thirty-four , with a humorous way about him , and a kindly expression . He holds the family living of Kenyon-Fulton , but there is nothing in him of the sanctimoniousness of the cloth . COBBETT is an agreeable youth of four-and-twenty . They are followed by CLAUDE INSOLEY .

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: Seeing EDITH LEWIS at the window .Are you going out ?

sp.speaker: EDITH
sp.p: We were — but we won ’ t .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I ’ ve been preparing Miss Lewis for your mother ’ s arrival .

sp.speaker: EDITH
sp.p: I ’ m beginning to tremble in my shoes .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: Our mother is what is usually described as a woman of character . With the best intentions in the world and the highest principles she succeeds in making life almost intolerable to every one connected with her .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: You won ’ t forget to send the carriage for her to-morrow , Grace ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I won ’ t .... Last time we sent the car by mistake , and she sent it back again .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: Good heavens , why did she do that ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Mrs. Insoley never has driven in a motor-car , and Mrs. Insoley never will drive in a motor-car .

lg.l: I don ’ t think you ought to make fun of my mother ,
Grace .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I wouldn ’ t if I could make anything else of her .

div.stage: As she says this she sits down at the piano and rattles her fingers over the keys .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Will you sing us a song , Mr. Cobbett ?

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: No , thank you .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I want to be amused .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: How desperately you say that !

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: To COBBETT .What will you sing ?

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: I ’ m afraid I don ’ t know anything that will fit the occasion .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I seem to have heard you warble a graceful little ditty about a top note .

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: Thank you very much , but I ’ m not fond of making a fool of myself .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Part of a gentleman ’ s education should be how to make himself ridiculous with dignity .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: To COBBETT .You make more fuss about singing than a young lady at a tea-party .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Looking at him with smiling lips but with hard eyes .Let us have no more maidenly coyness .

div.stage: She begins to play , and COBBETT , shrugging his shoulders , begins with rather bad grace to sing the song , “ I can ’ t reach that top note .” While they are in the middle of it the door opens , and the BUTLER announces MRS. INSOLEY and her companion . MRS. INSOLEY is a little old lady of some corpulence , shabbily dressed in rusty black . She looks rather like a charwoman in her Sunday best . MISS HALL , her companion , is a self-effacing silent person of uncertain age . She is always very anxious to make herself useful .

sp.speaker: MOORE
sp.p: Mrs. Insoley , Miss Hall .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Mother !

div.stage: The singing abruptly ceases . There is general consternation . MRS. INSOLEY stops still for one moment , and surveys the party with indignation . Then she sweeps into the room with such majesty as is compatible with her small size and considerable obesity .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: Is this a lunatic asylum that I have come into ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: We didn ’ t expect you till to-morrow .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: So I imagined by the fact that I found no conveyance at the station . I had to take a fly , and it cost me four-and-sixpence .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: But why didn ’ t you let us know you ’ d changed your plans , mother ?

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: I did let you know . I wrote to Grace yesterday . She must have got my letter this morning .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Oh , how stupid of me ! I recognised your writing , and as it was my birthday I thought I wouldn ’ t open it till to-morrow .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Grace !

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I ’ m dreadfully sorry .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: It was only by the mercy of Providence that I didn ’ t have to walk .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: There are always flies at the station .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: Providence might very well have caused them to be all engaged .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I don ’ t know why you should think Providence has nothing better to do than to play practical jokes on us .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: Looking round .And may I inquire why you have turned the house in which your father died into a bear garden ?

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: It ’ s Grace ’ s birthday , and we thought there would be no harm in our having a little fun .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: Putting up her face-à-main and staring at the company .I ’ m old-fashioned enough and well-bred enough to like people to be introduced to me .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Nowadays every one ’ s so disreputable that we think it safer not to make introductions .... This is Miss Lewis .

sp.speaker: EDITH
sp.p: How d ’ you do ?

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: Lewis !

lg.stage: With a little smile of amusement .
lg.l: I think you know Miss Vernon of
Foley .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: Very affably .Of course I know Miss Vernon of Foley . My dear Helen , you ’ re looking very handsome . It wants a woman of birth to wear the outrageous costumes of the present day .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: Shaking hands with her .It ’ s so nice of you to say so .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I forget if you know Mr. Cobbett .

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: How do you do ?

div.stage: He bows slightly as MRS. INSOLEY looks at him through her glasses .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: Cobbett !

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: With some asperity .Cobbett !

lg.l: We used to have a milkman called Cobbett ,
Louisa .

sp.speaker: MISS HALL
sp.p: Our milkman is called Wilkinson now .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: Very graciously .You were singing a song when I came in . What was it called ?

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: Rather sulkily .“ I can ’ t reach that top note .”

lg.l: I wondered why you were trying .... Why are you hiding behind that sofa ,
Archibald ? Do you not intend to kiss your mother ?

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: I ’ m delighted to see you , my dear mother .

div.stage: He kisses her on the forehead .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: I ’ m rather surprised to see a clergyman at a dinner-party on a Sunday night .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: I find two sermons a day excellent for the appetite . And the Bible tells us that corn makes the young men cheerful .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Smiling .Aren ’ t you dreadfully hungry ? Wouldn ’ t you like something to eat ?

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: No , I shall go straight to my room . It always upsets me to drive in a hired carriage .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I ’ ll just go and see that everything ’ s nice and comfortable .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: Pray don ’ t put yourself to any trouble on my account . It would distress me .

div.stage: GRACE goes out .

sp.speaker: EDITH
sp.p: Aside to MISS VERNON .Don ’ t you think we might go down to the lake ?

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: By all means .... There ’ s nothing I can get you , Mrs. Insoley ?

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: Graciously .Nothing , my dear Helen .

div.stage: MISS VERNON and EDITH LEWIS go out , and a moment later COBBETT slips out also .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: Claude , will you take Miss Hall into the dining-room and give her a sandwich and a glass of port ?

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Certainly .

sp.speaker: MISS HALL
sp.p: I don ’ t think I want anything , thank you , Mrs. Insoley .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: Nonsense , Louisa ! Allow me to know what is good for you . You ’ ll see that she drinks the port , Claude .As they go out .I want to talk to Archibald .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: My dear mother , I throw myself at your feet .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: With a chuckle .I very much doubt if you could . You ’ re growing much too fat . It ’ s quite time they made you something .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: Smiling .The landed gentry hasn ’ t its old power . Promotion in the Church nowadays is given with new-fangled ideas about merit and scholarship and heaven knows what .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: I hope you never eat potatoes or bread ?

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: I fly from them as I would from temptation .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: Nor soup ?

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: It is as the scarlet woman to me .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: And I trust you never touch green peas .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: Ah , there you have me . Even the saints had their weaknesses . I confess that when green peas are in season I always put on flesh .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: You want some one to keep a firm hand on you . You must marry .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: I saw you approaching that topic by leaps and bounds , mother .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: It ’ s a clergyman ’ s duty to marry .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: Chaffing her .St. Paul says ....

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: Interrupting .I know what St. Paul ’ s views were , Archibald , and I disagree with them .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: Dryly .I have every reason to believe he was of excellent family , mother .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: Giving him a quick look .We all know that it was a great disappointment to Helen Vernon when — you know what I mean .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: I can ’ t help thinking she showed bad taste in surviving the blow .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: It was a great disappointment to me . I had set my heart on joining Foley to Kenyon-Fulton .... It wouldn ’ t be too late even now if you had the sense to appreciate Helen Vernon ’ s affection for you .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: My dear mother , I can ’ t persuade myself for a moment that Helen Vernon has any affection for me .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: A woman of her age is prepared to have affection for any one who asks her to marry him .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: Even if he ’ s a poor country parson ?

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: You ’ re a great deal more than a country parson , Archibald . It is unlikely that Grace will have any children , so unless — something happens to allow Claude to marry again ....

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: What d ’ you mean by that , mother ?

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: Grace is not immortal .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: On the other hand , she has excellent health .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: There may be other ways of disposing of her .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: What ways ?

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: Looking at him calmly .Since when have you laboured under the delusion that I am the sort of woman to submit to cross-examination , Archibald ?

div.stage: The entrance of GRACE interrupts the conversation .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I hope I haven ’ t kept you waiting . I think you ’ ll find everything all right .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: In that case I shall go to my room . Archibald , tell Louisa that I am ready to go to my room .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: Certainly .

div.stage: He goes out , leaving GRACE alone with MRS. INSOLEY .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: Who is the young lady you have staying with you , Grace ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Edith Lewis . She ’ s a friend of mine .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: Ah ! And who is this Mr. Cobbett ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: He ’ s a friend of mine too .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: I didn ’ t imagine that you would invite total strangers to stay with you .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I don ’ t know that there ’ s any other way of describing them .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: I dare say that is a sufficient description in itself .

div.stage: MISS HALL comes back with CLAUDE and ARCHIBALD .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: I ’ m going to my room , Louisa . I shall be ready for you to read to me in a quarter of an hour .

sp.speaker: MISS HALL
sp.p: Very good , Mrs. Insoley .To GRACE .I suppose you don ’ t have prayers on Sunday night ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: No , we read our pedigree instead . You ’ ll find the “ Landed Gentry ” in your bedroom .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: Icily .In my young days it was thought more important for a young lady to be well-born than to be clever .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Chuckling .The result has been disastrous for the present generation .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: Good night .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Shaking hands cordially with MISS HALL .Be sure and let me know if you ’ re not quite comfortable . I hope you ’ ll find everything you want in your room .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: Of course Louisa will find everything she wants . She wants nothing . Come , Louisa .

div.stage: MRS. INSOLEY and MISS HALL go out .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: I think I ’ ll be toddling back to my rectory .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Oh , all right .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: Good night , Grace .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Good night .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: To ARCHIBALD .I talked to Gann about that matter .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: I ’ m afraid he ’ s going to make rather a nuisance of himself .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: I took a good firm line , you know .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: That ’ s right . It ’ s the only way with those sort of fellows . Good night , old man .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Good night .

div.stage: ARCHIBALD goes out .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: You were asking about Gann just now , Grace ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I was .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: At first I thought I ’ d better not tell you anything about it , but I ’ ve been thinking it over ....

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Interrupting .It was quite unnecessary . I ’ m not at all curious .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: I think perhaps it would be better if I told you what I ’ d done .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I ’ m sure that whatever you ’ ve done is right , Claude .Smiling .That ’ s why you ’ re so detestable .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: That ’ s all very fine and large , but I think I ’ d like to have your approval .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: We agreed very early in our married life that your acts were such as must necessarily meet with my approval .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: What ’ s the matter with you , Grace ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: With me ? Nothing .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: You ’ ve been so funny lately . I haven ’ t been able to make you out at all .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I should have thought you had more important things to do than to bother about me .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: I ’ ve got nothing in the world to do more important than to bother about you , Grace .

div.stage: She looks at him for an instant , with a catch in her breath .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Don ’ t worry me to-night , Claude ; my head ’ s aching so that I feel I could scream .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: With the tenderest concern .My poor child , why didn ’ t you tell me ? I ’ m so sorry I ’ ve been bothering you . Is it very bad ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: What a beast I am ! How can you like me when I ’ m so absolutely horrid to you ?

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: My darling , I don ’ t blame you for having a headache .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I ’ m sorry I was beastly to you just now .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: What nonsense !

div.stage: He tries to take her in his arms , but she draws herself away .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Please don ’ t , Claude .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Why don ’ t you go to bed , darling ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: With a cry of something like fright .Oh , no !

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Bed ’ s the best place for everybody at this hour .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I want to amuse myself . Go and fetch the others , they ’ re down by the lake . And we ’ ll all play poker .

div.stage: He is just going to make an observation , but she bursts in vehemently .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: For God ’ s sake do as I ask you .

div.stage: He looks at her . With a shrug of the shoulders he goes out into the garden . GRACE gives a deep sigh . In a moment HENRY COBBETT enters . GRACE looks at him silently as he advances into the room .

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: I ’ ve been waiting for the chance of speaking to you by yourself .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Have you ?

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: Why did you make me sing that idiotic song just now ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Her eyes cold and hostile .Because I chose .

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: You made me look a perfect fool .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: That ’ s what I wanted to make you look .

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: Surprised .Did you ? Why ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I have no explanation to offer .

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: You know , I ’ m hanged if I can make you out . You ’ re never the same for two minutes together .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Frigidly .I suppose it is disconcerting . Claude complains of it too .

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: Oh , hang Claude .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: You ’ re growing more and more like him every day , Harry .

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: I don ’ t quite know what you mean by that .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: It seems hardly worth while to have — made a long journey to find oneself exactly where one started .

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: I never know what people are driving at when they talk metaphorically .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Looking at him deliberately .I thought I loved you , Harry .

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: You ’ ve said it often enough .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Slowly .I wonder if I just said it to persuade myself . My heart ’ s empty ! Empty ! I know now that it wasn ’ t love I felt for you .

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: It ’ s rather late in the day to have found that out , isn ’ t it ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Bitterly .Yes , that ’ s just it . It ’ s late in the day for everything .... Here they are .

div.stage: A sound of talking is heard as EDITH LEWIS approaches with HELEN VERNON and CLAUDE .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: At the window .I found them on their way back .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: To COBBETT , with a little bitter laugh .We ’ re going to play poker . END OF THE FIRST ACT

div.head: THE SECOND ACT

stage.stage: THE SCENE is the same as in the preceding Act . It is evening , towards seven o ’ clock , but it is still perfectly light . GRACE and PEGGY GANN are in the room , both standing . PEGGY is a pretty girl , quite young , but very pale , with black rings round her eyes . She is dressed like a housemaid in her going-out things . GRACE is evidently much distressed .

sp.speaker: PEGGY
sp.p: You will try , mum , won ’ t you ?

div.stage: PEGGY ’ S voice seems to call GRACE back with a start from her own thoughts .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I ought to have been told before . It was wicked to keep it from me .

sp.speaker: PEGGY
sp.p: I thought you knew , mum . I wasn ’ t to know that you ’ adn ’ t been told anything .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: With a friendly smile .I ’ m not blaming you , Peggy .... Mr. Insoley ’ s out now , but I ’ ll talk to him as soon as she come in . You ’ d better go home and fetch your father .

sp.speaker: PEGGY
sp.p: You know what father is , mum . I ’ m afraid he won ’ t come .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Oh , but I think it ’ s very important . Tell him that ....

div.stage: HENRY COBBETT comes in , and she stops when she sees him .

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: Hulloa , am I in the way ? Shall I go ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Passing her hand wearily across her forehead .No . I ’ ve just finished .... Try and get your father to come , Peggy .

sp.speaker: PEGGY
sp.p: Well , I ’ ll do what I can , mum .

div.stage: She goes out . GRACE gives a little exclamation , partly of distress , partly of indignation .

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: What ’ s the matter ? You seem rather put out .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: That ’ s the daughter of one of the keepers . She came to me just now and asked me to beg Claude to give them a little more time . I hadn ’ t an idea what she meant . Then she said Claude had told her father he must send her away within twenty-four hours or lose his place .

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: Flippantly .Oh , yes , I know . She seems to be rather a flighty young person . Claude and your brother-in-law were talking about it after lunch in the smoking-room .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Why didn ’ t you tell me ?

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: Well , it never struck me you didn ’ t know . Besides — you haven ’ t shown any great desire for my society the last day or two .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: With a quick look at him .I ’ ve had other guests to attend to .

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: Shrugging his shoulders .And it seemed rather a sordid little story . I don ’ t think I can interest myself very much at this time of day in the gamekeeper ’ s daughter who kicks over the traces .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Sarcastically .It ’ s so devilish mid-Victorian , isn ’ t it ?

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: Surprised at her tone .It ’ s not really bothering you , is it ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: With a sudden vehement outburst .Don ’ t you see that wretched girl has done no more than I have ?

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: With a chuckle .Great Scott , you haven ’ t produced an unexpected baby , have you ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Oh , don ’ t , don ’ t .

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: Coolly .In point of fact she ’ s done a great deal more than you have . She ’ s been found out .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: How can you be so odiously cynical ?

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: I notice people always call you odiously cynical when you talk plain horse-sense to them .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Can ’ t you realise what I ’ m feeling ? She had excuses . She was alone , and little more than a child ; she had no education . How could she be expected to resist temptation ?

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: It ’ s an absolute delusion that the lower classes are less able to resist temptation than their betters . In the first place , they have a much more systematic moral education , and then they ’ re taught from early youth to look upon virtue as a valuable asset .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Going up to him suddenly .Harry , would you mind very much if I stopped the whole thing ?

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: Of course I should mind .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Oh , no , don ’ t say that because it ’ s the conventional thing to say . I want you to be frank with me .

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: Uneasily .Why do you ask me now ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: After a look at him , a little unwillingly .I feel so horribly mean .

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: Claude ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: With a sort of appeal , as if she were excusing herself .He ’ s so awfully good to me , Harry . Every present he gives me , every kind word is like a stab in my heart . I ’ m beastly to him sometimes , I can ’ t help it , but nothing seems to make any difference to him .... Whatever I do , he loves me .

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: Are you beginning to care for Claude — differently ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Oh , it ’ s no use pretending . I never loved him as he loved me . I couldn ’ t . I was bored by his love . Yes , all the time we ’ ve been married .... It ’ s only lately ....

div.stage: She pauses abruptly . COBBETT gives her a sidelong glance .

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: Oh !

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I don ’ t know what I feel or what to do . I ’ m so bewildered and wretched .... He bores me still — oh , horribly sometimes . And yet at moments I feel as though I were a good deal more than half in love with him . It ’ s too absurd . With Claude — after all these years . Something has changed me .... It ’ s the last thing that ought to have changed me towards him .

div.stage: She flushes hotly , and again COBBETT looks at her , and a rather sulky expression comes into his face .

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: It ’ s not a very pleasant position for me , is it ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I shouldn ’ t have thought it ever had been a very pleasant position considering what a good friend Claude has been to you .

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: If you look at it in that way , I dare say it would be better to put an end to the whole thing .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: You have been rather a blackguard , haven ’ t you ?

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: No . I don ’ t pretend to be better than anybody else , but I ’ m quite certain I ’ m no worse . I ’ m a perfectly normal man in good health . It ’ s idiotic to abuse me because I ’ ve done what any other fellow would have done in my place .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Suddenly understanding .Is that all it was to you ?

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: What d ’ you mean ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Wasn ’ t I anything to you at all ? Only a more or less attractive woman who happened to cross your path ? If I was only that , why couldn ’ t you leave me alone ? What harm did I ever do you ? Oh , it was cruel of you . Cruel !

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: Quietly .No man ’ s able to have an affair all by himself , you know .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: What d ’ you mean by that ?

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: Well , most fellows are very shy , and they ’ re dreadfully frightened of a rebuff . A man doesn ’ t take much risk until — well , until he finds there ’ s not much risk to take .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: D ’ you mean to say I gave you to understand .... Oh , how can you humiliate me like that ?

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: Isn ’ t there a certain amount of truth in it ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Looking as it were into her own soul .Yes .... Oh , I ’ m so ashamed .

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: The world would be a jolly sight easier place to live in if people weren ’ t such humbugs .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Hardly able to believe the truth that presents itself to her , yet eager to probe it .D ’ you think it was only curiosity on my side and nothing more than opportunity on yours ?

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: That ’ s the foundation of nine love affairs out of ten , you know .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Trying to justify herself in her own eyes .I was so bored — so lonely . I never felt at home with the people I had to live with . They humiliated me . And you seemed the same sort of person as I was . I felt at my ease with you . At first I thought you cared for the things I cared for — music and books and pictures : it took me quite a time to discover that you didn ’ t know the difference between a fiddle and a jews ’ harp .... I wonder why you troubled to take me in .

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: I naturally talked about what I thought would please you .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I remember at first I felt as if I were just stepping out of a prison into the fresh air . It seemed to me as if — oh , I don ’ t know how to put it — as if spring flowers were suddenly blossoming in my heart .

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: I ’ m afraid you were asking more from me than I was able to give you .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Oh , I don ’ t blame you . You ’ re quite right : it ’ s I who am to blame .With sudden vehemence .Oh , how I envy that wretched girl ! If she fell it was because she loved . I asked her who the man was , and she wouldn ’ t tell me . She said she didn ’ t want to get him into trouble . She must love him still .

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: Moved by the pain which he sees she is suffering .I hope you don ’ t think me an awful skunk , Grace . I ’ m sorry we ’ ve made such a hash of things .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Going on with her own thoughts .It would be horrible if that wretched girl were punished while I go scot-free . I can ’ t let her be turned away like a leper . I should never rest in peace again .

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: Claude ’ s not very fond of going back on his word . He seems to have delivered an ultimatum , and I expect he ’ ll stick to it .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: It means so much to me . I feel somehow that if I can only save that poor child it ’ ll make up in a way — oh , very little — for all the harm I ’ ve done .... D ’ you think I ’ m perfectly absurd ?

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: Life seems devilish complicated sometimes , doesn ’ t it ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: With a smile .Devilish .

div.stage: The sound is heard of a carriage stopping outside .

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: Hulloa , what ’ s that ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: It ’ s my mother-in-law . She ’ s been out for her drive .With a glance at her watch .Claude ought to be in soon .

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: What are you going to do ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I ’ m going to use every means in my power to persuade him to change his mind .

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: You ’ re not going to do anything foolish , Grace ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: How d ’ you mean ?His meaning suddenly strikes her .You don ’ t think I might have to .... Oh , that would be too much to ask me .... D ’ you think I might have to tell him ?

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: Whatever you do , Grace , I want you to know that if anything happens I ’ m willing to do the straight thing .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Shaking her head .No , I should never ask you to marry me . Now we both know how things are between us — how they ’ ve always been ....

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: I ’ m awfully sorry , Grace .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: There ’ s no need to be . I ’ m glad to know the truth . There was nothing that held us together before but my cowardice . I was so afraid of going back to that dreary loneliness . But you ’ ve given me courage .

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: Is there nothing left of it at all ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: So far as I ’ m concerned nothing at all — but shame .

div.stage: EDITH LEWIS comes in . GRACE , recovering herself quickly , throws off her seriousness and greets the girl with a pleasant smile .

sp.speaker: EDITH
sp.p: We ’ ve had such a lovely drive .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: And d ’ you think the country ’ s as beautiful as ever ?

sp.speaker: EDITH
sp.p: Gaily .Oh , I didn ’ t look at the country . I was much too excited . Mrs. Insoley has been telling me the dreadful pasts of all the families in the neighbourhood . It appears the further they go back the more shocking their behaviour has been .

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: I notice that even the grossest immorality becomes respectable when it ’ s a hundred years old .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Ironically .It ’ s very hard , isn ’ t it ? Mrs. Grundy has no mercy . She ’ ll take even you to her bosom before you know where you are .

div.stage: Enter MRS. INSOLEY , followed by MISS VERNON and MISS HALL . MISS HALL is carrying MRS. INSOLEY ’ S lap-dog .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I hope you enjoyed your drive .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: I didn ’ t go for my enjoyment , Grace ; I went to exercise the horses .

lg.l: Meanwhile , I hear you took the opportunity of enlarging
Edith ’ s young mind .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: To EDITH .When you come to Foley you must remind me to show you the portraits of my great-grandmother , Mary Vernon . She had a tremendous affair with the Regent , you know .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: Pleasantly .My dear Helen , I have the greatest affection for you , but I cannot allow a statement like that to go unchallenged . There is no evidence whatever of the truth of it .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: I don ’ t know how you can say that , Mrs. Insoley , considering that I have all my great-grandmother ’ s letters to the Regent .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: With a chuckle .Where are his letters to your great-grandmother ?

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: She gave them back at the time he returned hers , naturally .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: I can see her . If she had any letters she would have kept them . Any woman would .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: Bridling a little .I can ’ t imagine why you should suddenly throw doubts on a story that the whole county has believed for a hundred years . Every one knew all about Mary Vernon .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: Chaffing her .I am aware that your great-grandmother was an abandoned hussy , but that in itself is no proof that she ever had anything to do with the Regent .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: You can ’ t deny that he slept at Foley , Mrs. Insoley .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: Only one night .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: It ’ s notorious that at that very time he was on terms of the greatest intimacy with Pamela Bainbridge .To EDITH LEWIS .I am not an Insoley , thank God ; I am a Bainbridge . And whenever he came to this part of the country he stayed with us .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: I know you ’ ve always flattered yourself that there was something between them .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: With complete self-assurance .And well I may , considering that I still have a lock of hair which he gave my grandmother .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: Half the families in the country have a greasy lock of hair which they tell you was the Regent ’ s . Personally , I think it ’ s rather snobbish to make a claim of that sort unless one ’ s perfectly sure .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: Bridling in her turn .I think you ’ re extremely rude , Helen . In the presence of a man I can ’ t go into details , but I have proof of every word I say . You know what I mean , Louisa ?

sp.speaker: MISS HALL
sp.p: I believed the worst from the beginning , Mrs. Insoley .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: I have no doubt you firmly believe what you say , Mrs. Insoley ; but if you don ’ t mind my saying so , one has only to look at the portrait of Pamela Bainbridge to know the whole thing ’ s absurd .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: Frigidly .We won ’ t argue the point , Helen ; I know I ’ m right , and there ’ s an end of it .... Put the dog on that chair , Louisa .

sp.speaker: MISS HALL
sp.p: That ’ s Mr. Cobbett ’ s chair , Mrs. Insoley .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: Still a little out of temper .Has Mr. Cobbett bought it ?

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: No , but Mr. Cobbett ’ s been sitting in it .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: And may no one use a chair that Mr. Cobbett has been sitting in ?

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: Certainly . But it so happens that Mr. Cobbett is just going to sit in it again .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: With a grim smile .Mr. Cobbett has legs .

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: Only two , and if a merciful Providence had intended him to stand on them it would undoubtedly have provided him with four .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: Mr. Cobbett seems to be better acquainted with the designs of Providence than I should have expected .... Louisa , give me the dog . He shall sit on my lap .

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: Chaffing her .Ah , if you ’ d only told me that was the alternative , of course I wouldn ’ t have hesitated for a moment .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: I think you are very vulgar , sir .... I ’ m surprised that you should laugh at such an inane joke , Grace .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: You forget that I have a naturally vulgar nature .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: I try to , but you take great pains to remind me .

div.stage: CLAUDE comes in with ARCHIBALD .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Well , did you enjoy your drive , mother ?

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: I didn ’ t go for my enjoyment , Claude ; I went to exercise the horses .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: We ’ ve been to a parish meeting .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Rather peevishly .It ’ s getting almost impossible to do anything for these Somersetshire people . They ’ re such an obstinate , pig-headed lot .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: I prophesied it forty years ago . When they first introduced all this nonsense about education , I said it was a serious matter .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: With a twinkle in his eye .Like all good prophets you apparently took care to be rather vague about it , mother .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: Considering you weren ’ t born I don ’ t see what you can know about it , Archibald . I said this would happen . I said they would make the lower classes so independent that no one would be able to do anything with them . I went for a walk in the village this morning and nobody took any notice of me . Isn ’ t that so , Louisa ?

sp.speaker: MISS HALL
sp.p: No , Mrs. Insoley .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: What do you mean by no , Louisa ?

sp.speaker: MISS HALL
sp.p: Hastily .I beg your pardon . I mean yes , Mrs. Insoley .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: A few old men touched their hats , and one old woman curtsied , but that was all .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: With a little nod .Of course it ’ s not important in itself , but it ’ s the sign of a change . The long and short of it is that they don ’ t look up to their betters as they used to .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Ironically .Perhaps they ’ ve ceased to realise that we are their betters .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: It ’ s not too late to teach them their mistake . Personally I mean to be master in my own house .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Abruptly .Peggy Gann came to see me this afternoon , Claude .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Did she ?

div.stage: There is a very short pause . COBBETT sees what is going to happen and gets up .

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: To EDITH LEWIS .Wouldn ’ t you like to come for a stroll in the garden ?

sp.speaker: EDITH LEWIS
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I ’ ve asked her to fetch her father .

div.stage: COBBETT and EDITH LEWIS go out .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Without waiting for the movement .I ’ m sorry you did that , Grace . I ’ ve got nothing to say to him .

lg.l: Do you know that Claude has threatened to dismiss
Gann if Peggy hasn ’ t gone by ten o ’ clock to-night ?

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: For once in his life Claude has acted with spirit . He gave Gann twenty-four hours to think it over . My father would have given him fifteen minutes .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Why was it all kept from me ? It seems that everybody knew but me .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Hang it all , Grace , I wanted to tell you last night and you wouldn ’ t let me .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Startled .Oh ! Was it that ? I didn ’ t know .... Claude , I want you to be very kind and forgive that wretched girl . I want you to tell Gann that she needn ’ t go .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Quite firmly .My dear , I can ’ t do that . I ’ ve made up my mind and I must stick to it .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Hang it all , what would happen to the discipline of the estate if I were always shilly-shallying ? Every one in the place knows that when I say a thing I mean it . It ’ s an enormous advantage to all concerned .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: With a coaxing smile .It wouldn ’ t do any harm if you made an exception just this once .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: It ’ s a matter of upholding my authority . Gann refused to do what I told him , and I had to threaten him with immediate dismissal . I couldn ’ t eat my words now without looking a perfect fool .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Don ’ t you think it ’ s awfully unjust to send a girl away because she ’ s got into trouble ?

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: It ’ s a rule of the estate . I didn ’ t make it .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Turning to MISS VERNON .Helen , you ’ re a woman . You must see how cruel it is . Can ’ t you say something to help me ?

lg.l: I don ’ t know what else one ’ s to do . After all , we have the same rule at
Foley .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: They have it on half the large estates in the kingdom . It ’ s absolutely essential if one has any regard for decency .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: I don ’ t suppose it would be so common , and it certainly wouldn ’ t have lasted so long , if there hadn ’ t been some good in it .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Violently .Oh , it ’ s maddening . Always , always , there ’ s that stone wall in front of me . Whatever is , is good . However cruel and unjust a custom is , no one must touch it because it ’ s a custom . If a law is infamous , does it become any less infamous because people have suffered from it for a dozen generations ?

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: Perhaps you ’ re not very competent to judge matters of this sort , my dear .

lg.l: I ’ m afraid your sympathy is rather wasted in this particular case . Peggy
Gann isn ’ t a very deserving young woman .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: If she were , there ’ d be no need for me to plead for her .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: On those lines the more of a hussy a girl is the more she ’ s deserving of sympathy .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: To ARCHIBALD .You had nothing against her till this happened .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: Nothing very definite . She was always rather cheeky , and she never came to Sunday-school very regularly .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Is that all ?

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: My own belief is that the Ganns are really Dissenters .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Impatiently .Good heavens , they positively revel in going to church .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: That may be or it may not . But they give me the impression of chapel people .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: Heaven knows , I don ’ t want to seem hard and unsympathetic , but after all , you ’ re not going to keep people moral if you pamper those who aren ’ t .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: And what d ’ you think ’ ll happen to her if you make her leave here ?

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: We ’ ll do our best for her . It ’ s not a pleasant position for any of us , Grace . I ’ ve been wretched about the whole thing , and I ’ m sure Claude has too .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Of course I have . But hang it all , in our position we can ’ t afford to think of sentiment . Especially now that they ’ re attacking us all round we ’ ve got to show them that we can keep a firm hand on the reins .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: Do us the justice to see that we ’ re really trying to do what ’ s right . It may be very wrong that we should be in our particular positions , and we may be quite unworthy of them . But we didn ’ t make society , and we ’ re not responsible for its inequalities . We find ourselves in a certain station , and we have to act accordingly .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: The long and the short of it is that it ’ s our duty to look after those whom Providence has placed in our charge . And it ’ s our duty to punish as well as to reward .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Oh , how hard you are ! One would think you ’ d never done anything in your life that you regret .With increasing violence .Oh , you virtuous people , I hate you . You ’ re never content till you see the sinner actually frizzling . As if hell were needed when every sin brings its own punishment ! And you never make excuses . You don ’ t know how many temptations we resist for the one we fall to .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: Grace ! What are you saying !

div.stage: GRACE , almost beside herself , looks at her with haggard eyes . Suddenly she gives a start , and stares at MISS VERNON with horror . She has realised that MISS VERNON knows the relations that have existed between her and HENRY COBBETT . There is a pause . The BUTLER comes in .

sp.speaker: MOORE
sp.p: Gann and his daughter are here , sir .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Oh , yes , I ’ ll come at once .

sp.speaker: MOORE
sp.p: Very good , sir .

div.stage: He goes out .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: Why shouldn ’ t he come here , Claude ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Yes , let him come by all means . And then you can see for yourselves .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: I ’ ll tell Moore , shall I ?He goes to the door as he says this and calls .Moore . Tell Gann to come here .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: Rising .I think I ’ ll leave you . This isn ’ t any business of mine .To MISS HALL .Will you come with me ?

sp.speaker: MISS HALL
sp.p: Do you want me , Mrs. Insoley ?

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: No . You ’ ve had no exercise to-day , Louisa . You ’ d better walk three times round the garden .

sp.speaker: MISS HALL
sp.p: I ’ m not very well to-day , Mrs. Insoley .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: Oh , nonsense ! You ’ re in the best of health . And you can take the dog with you .

sp.speaker: MISS HALL
sp.p: Very well , Mrs. Insoley .

div.stage: MISS VERNON and MISS HALL go out .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: Louisa ’ s very troublesome sometimes . She fancies she ’ s not feeling well . But she ’ s twenty-five years younger than I am , and I ’ ve never had a day ’ s illness in my life .

div.stage: MOORE opens the door for GANN , who comes into the room , cap in hand , and stands at the door awkwardly . He is in his working clothes .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Good afternoon , Gann .

sp.speaker: GANN
sp.p: Good afternoon , sir . Peggy said you wished to see me , sir .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I asked her to bring you here , Gann . I thought it would be better if you spoke to Mr. Insoley .

sp.speaker: GANN
sp.p: I ’ ve got nothing to say to Mr. Insoley , ma ’ am .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: I was hoping to find you in a more reasonable state of mind , Gann . You know , you can only hurt yourself by being pig-headed and stubborn .

sp.speaker: GANN
sp.p: I didn ’ t know as how I was , sir .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: To GRACE .You see , the man doesn ’ t give me a chance .

sp.speaker: GANN
sp.p: Making an effort on himself .Please , Squire , I come to know if I ’ m really to go to-morrow ? I know you said you ’ d send me away , Squire . But I couldn ’ t bring myself to believe you meant it .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: I ’ m willing to listen to anything you ’ ve got to say . I want to be quite fair to you .

sp.speaker: GANN
sp.p: If I could only make you see as what you ask ain ’ t possible , I ’ m sure you ’ d let us stay . There ’ s nowhere Peggy can go to .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Hang it all , Mrs. Insoley ’ ll do all she can for her . You may be quite sure that Peggy shan ’ t want for money .

sp.speaker: GANN
sp.p: It isn ’ t money the girl wants . If I send ’ er away she ’ ll just go to the bad altogether .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: You see , it ’ s a matter of principle , Gann . It would be devilish unjust to make an exception in your favour .

sp.speaker: GANN
sp.p: Stepping forward with surly indignation and facing CLAUDE .I love the girl and I can ’ t bear to part with ’ er . She ’ s a good girl in her ’ eart , only she ’ s had a misfortune .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: That ’ s all very fine and large , Gann . But if she ’ d been a good girl , hang it all , she ’ d have had power to resist temptation .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Terrified .Claude , you don ’ t know what you ’ re saying .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: I don ’ t want to rub it in and all that sort of thing , but my own feeling is that if she came rather a cropper , it was because she was — if you don ’ t mind my saying so — because she was that way inclined . I don ’ t think anyone can accuse me of being a hard man , but I ’ m afraid I haven ’ t much pity for women who ....

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Interrupting .Claude , don ’ t go on — for God ’ s sake .

sp.speaker: GANN
sp.p: That ’ s your last word , Squire ? If the girl don ’ t go , I must ?

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: I ’ m afraid so .

sp.speaker: GANN
sp.p: I ’ ve served you faithful , man and boy , for forty years . And I was born in that there cottage I live in now . If you turn us out where are we to go to ? I ’ m getting on in years , and I shan ’ t find it easy to get another job . It ’ ll mean the work ’ us .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: I ’ m very sorry . I can ’ t do anything for you . You ’ ve had your chance and you ’ ve refused to take it .

div.stage: GANN turns his cap round nervously . His face is distorted with agony . He opens his mouth to speak , but no words come , only an inarticulate groan . He turns on his heel .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: In consideration of your long service I ’ ll give you fifty pounds so that you can tide over the next few months .

sp.speaker: GANN
sp.p: Violently .You can keep your dirty money .

div.stage: He goes out . GRACE goes up to CLAUDE desperately .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Oh , Claude , you can ’ t do it . You ’ ll break the man ’ s heart . Haven ’ t you any pity ? Haven ’ t you any forgiveness ?

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: It ’ s no good , Grace . I must stick to what I ’ ve said .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: It ’ s not often I ’ ve begged you to do anything for me .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Well , hang it all , this is the first time I ’ ve ever refused .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Bitterly .I suppose because I ’ ve never asked you for anything before that wasn ’ t absolutely trifling .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: Why are you making such a point of it , Grace ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Is it very strange that I should feel sorry for anyone who ’ s in distress ?

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: I ’ ll do anything in the world to please you , darling , but in this case you must trust to my better judgment .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: How can you be so hard ?

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Come , Grace , don ’ t be angry with me . It ’ s bad enough as it is .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: I have no patience with you , Claude . When your father made up his mind to do anything it was done , and it would never have occurred to me to oppose him .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: With a twinkle in his eye .You forget , mother , that was because you generally made up my father ’ s mind some time before he did .

lg.l: Will you leave me alone with
Claude . I must talk to him alone .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: Come , mother . Let me take you for a stroll three times round the garden .

div.stage: MRS. INSOLEY and ARCHIBALD go out .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I couldn ’ t say it before them . They ’ d never understand . They ’ d only sneer . But can ’ t you see , Claude , that it ’ s out of the question to drive Gann away so callously ? He loves the place just as much as you love it .... In my heart I seem to feel suddenly all that his shabby little cottage means to him — the woods and coverts and the meadows and the trees . His life is bound up with Kenyon . His roots are in the earth as if he were a growing thing . Can ’ t you see what it must mean to him to leave it ?

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: He only goes because he ’ s headstrong and obstinate . He ’ s the Somersetshire peasant all over . You do your best for them and you get no gratitude . You try to reason with them , but you can ’ t get a single idea into their thick heads .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: You can ’ t punish him because he ’ s stupid and dull . You ’ re throwing him upon the world in his old age . It means starvation .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: You must know that I ’ m only doing it because I think it ’ s my duty .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Impatiently .Oh , men always talk of their duty when they want to be odiously cruel .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Grace , how can you be so unkind to me ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Oh , Claude , if you love me at all , give in to me this time . You don ’ t know what it means to me . I ’ ve often been horrible to you , but I ’ m going to be different . I want to love you . I want to be more to you than I ’ ve ever been . Claude , I implore you to do what I ask you — just because I ask it , because you love me .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Withdrawing himself a little .I could not love you , dear , so much , loved I not honour ....

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Interrupting passionately .Oh , no , don ’ t , Claude ; for God ’ s sake be sincere and natural . Can ’ t you forget that you ’ re a landed proprietor and a J. P. and all the rest of it , and remember that you ’ re only a man , as weak and as — as frail as the rest of us ? You hope to be forgiven yourself , and you ’ re utterly pitiless .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: My darling , it ’ s just as much for your sake that I ’ m firm .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Impatiently .Oh , how can you make phrases ! What on earth have I got to do with it ?

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Hang it all , don ’ t you see that it ’ s because of you that I can ’ t give way ? It ’ s beastly having to say it . It makes me feel such an ass .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Beginning to be frightened .What have I got to do with it ?

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Until I knew you I don ’ t suppose I had a higher opinion of women than most men , but you taught me what a — what a stunning fine thing a good woman is .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Hoarsely .It ’ s perfectly absurd . It ’ s — it ’ s unreasonable . I ’ ve not been .... Only the other day you said I was cold . And just now you told me I was unkind .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: I dare say that ’ s all my fault . I expect I bore you sometimes . After all , I know you ’ re worth about six of me . I can ’ t expect you to love me as I love you .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: D ’ you mean to say that if I weren ’ t — what you think me , you wouldn ’ t insist on that poor girl going away ?

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: I don ’ t suppose I should feel quite the same about it .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Trying to keep back her sobs .It ’ s so unreasonable .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Even if it weren ’ t for the rule of the estate , I couldn ’ t let her live in the same place as you . I can ’ t help it . It ’ s just a sort of instinct . It simply disgusts me to think that you may meet that — that woman when you walk about , and her kid .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Oh , Claude , you don ’ t know what you ’ re saying .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: When I heard she ’ d been here and you ’ d been talking to her , I felt almost sick .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Breaking down .Oh , I can ’ t bear it .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Come , darling , don ’ t let ’ s quarrel any more . It hurts me so awfully .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: To herself .Oh , I can ’ t . I can ’ t .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Say you forgive me , darling .

lg.l: I ?... If I weren ’ t what you .... Oh , it ’ s too much to ask anyone . Claude ,
I beseech you to give way .

div.stage: He shakes his head . She falls back in despair , realising that there is no way to move him .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Oh , what a punishment !

div.stage: The sound of a gong is heard . CLAUDE looks at his watch .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: By Jove , I had no idea it was so late . There ’ s the dressing gong . You must hurry up .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Looking at him vaguely .What is it ?

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Time to dress for dinner , darling . You won ’ t be late , will you ? You know how mother hates to be kept waiting .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Dully .No , I won ’ t be late .

div.stage: He takes her hand and presses it , then hurries out . She has given him her hand inertly , and it falls heavily to her side as he drops it . She remains standing where he left her . She tries to stifle the tearless sobs that seem to choke her . The BUTLER comes in .

sp.speaker: MOORE
sp.p: Peggy Gann wishes to know if you want to see her again , madam .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: With a start .Has she been waiting all this time ?

sp.speaker: MOORE
sp.p: Yes ’ m . She didn ’ t know as Gann had left . He never come back to the servants ’ hall .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Tell her to come here .

sp.speaker: MOORE
sp.p: Very good , madam .

div.stage: He goes out . In a moment he opens the door for PEGGY GANN .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Oh , Peggy , how ill you look ! I ’ ve been able to do nothing for you .

sp.speaker: PEGGY
sp.p: With a cry of distress .Oh , mum , I was hoping . You said you ’ d do your best for me .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: My dear , I ’ m so dreadfully sorry for you .

sp.speaker: PEGGY
sp.p: It ’ s so ’ ard on me , mum , and so ’ ard on father . Wasn ’ t there something more you could do , mum ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: With a little gasp of anguish .I did all I could . I couldn ’ t do anything more . I couldn ’ t really ....Almost to herself .It ’ s too much to ask anyone .

sp.speaker: PEGGY
sp.p: I ’ ve got to go then , and there ’ s an end of it . You won ’ t let father be turned away , will you , mum ? That ’ s all I care about now . It ’ ud just break his ’ eart .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: With a ray of hope .D ’ you think he ’ ll let you go ? I think it ’ s the best thing after all , Peggy . I ’ ve done — I ’ ve done all I could .

sp.speaker: PEGGY
sp.p: No , he won ’ t hear of it . But I shall go all the same — somewhere he can ’ t find me .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Anxious now to make the best of it .I dare say it won ’ t be for very long , Peggy . Have you as much money as you want ? I should like to do something for you .

sp.speaker: PEGGY
sp.p: I shan ’ t want anything , thank you , mum . And thank you for all you ’ ve done . And if anything come to ’ appen to me , you ’ d see as the baby wasn ’ t sent to the workhouse , wouldn ’ t you , mum ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: How d ’ you mean ? I don ’ t understand .

sp.speaker: PEGGY
sp.p: I ’ m not going to take the baby with me , mum . It would only be a hindrance .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: With a sigh of relief .Oh , I was so afraid you meant ....

sp.speaker: PEGGY
sp.p: Is there anything else you want me for , mum ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: No , Peggy .

sp.speaker: PEGGY
sp.p: Then I ’ ll say good evening , mum .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Good evening , Peggy .

div.stage: She watches PEGGY go out , then she gives a little moan of despair .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: No , I couldn ’ t , I couldn ’ t . EDITH LEWIS comes in gaily .

sp.speaker: EDITH LEWIS
sp.p: There you are ! I thought you were in your room . Your maid said you hadn ’ t come up yet .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Wearily .I was just going .

sp.speaker: EDITH LEWIS
sp.p: With a smile .I ’ ve got something dreadfully important to ask you .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Forcing a smile .What is it ?

sp.speaker: EDITH LEWIS
sp.p: Well , I want to know if you ’ re going to wear the grey satin you wore on Saturday . You see , I only brought three dinner dresses down with me , and one of them ’ s a grey , only it ’ s much more slaty than yours , and it ’ ll look so cold beside it .
