So I shan ’ t put it on if you ’ re going to wear yours .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Dully .No , I won ’ t wear my grey satin .

sp.speaker: EDITH LEWIS
sp.p: What are you going to wear ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I don ’ t know .

sp.speaker: EDITH LEWIS
sp.p: But you must know .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Does it matter ?

sp.speaker: EDITH LEWIS
sp.p: I don ’ t want to clash with you .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Clenching her hands to prevent herself from screaming .I won ’ t put on anything that ’ ll interfere with your grey .

sp.speaker: EDITH LEWIS
sp.p: Thank you . Now I can be quite happy . I say , we shall be so late .She runs off . GRACE gives a little answering laugh to hers ; and as EDITH LEWIS goes out , it lengthens into a mirthless , low , hysterical peal , broken with sobs .END OF THE SECOND ACT

div.head: THE THIRD ACT
div.stage: The dining-room at Kenyon Fulton . It is a fine room with French windows leading into the garden . On the walls are departed Insoleys of the last two or three generations , stiff ladies and gentlemen of the Victorian era , military-looking fellows in the uniform of the early nineteenth century , and ungainly Georgian squires with their wives in powdered hair . Between the windows , standing well away from the wall , rather far back , is a round table laid out for breakfast . On the Sheraton sideboard is a cloth , a stand for keeping dishes warm , a large ham , and plates and forks and spoons . Against the wall opposite the sideboard are a row of chairs , and there are half a dozen chairs round the table . There are doors right and left . It is the morning after the events which occur in the Second Act , and when the curtain rises prayers have just finished . CLAUDE is seated at the table with an immense prayer-book and a still larger Bible in front of him . The rest of the party are rising to their feet . They have been kneeling against various chairs . They consist of MRS. INSOLEY , MISS HALL , and MISS VERNON . Well away from them , emphasising the fact that even the Almighty must recognise the difference between the gentry and their inferiors , have been praying the servants . They have been kneeling against the row of chairs that line the wall , according to their precedence , ranging from the COOK at one end to the BUTLER at the other ; and they consist of the COOK , obese , elderly and respectable , MRS. INSOLEY ’ S MAID , two HOUSEMAIDS , the KITCHENMAID , the FOOTMAN , and MOORE the butler . When they have scrambled to their feet they pause for a moment to gather themselves together , and , headed by the COOK , walk out . The BUTLER takes the Bible and the prayer-book off the table and carries them away . CLAUDE gets up . He takes up his letters and the Times , which he puts under his arm .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: I didn ’ t see Grace ’ s maid , Claude .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: I dare say Grace couldn ’ t spare her .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: If Grace were more punctual she wouldn ’ t be obliged to deprive her maid of the pleasure and the duty of attending morning prayers .

sp.speaker: MISS HALL
sp.p: I didn ’ t see your maid either , Miss Vernon .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: She ’ s a Roman Catholic .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: A Papist , Helen ? Isn ’ t that very risky ?

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: Good gracious me , why ?

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: Aren ’ t you afraid she ’ ll corrupt the other servants ?

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: With a smile .She ’ s a highly respectable person of well over forty .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: She must be very flighty . I would as soon have an atheist .

sp.speaker: MISS HALL
sp.p: I would never dream of having a Romish maid myself .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: Is there any likelihood of your having a maid at all , Louisa ?

sp.speaker: MISS HALL
sp.p: No , Mrs. Insoley .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: In that case I can ’ t quite see what is the use of your having an opinion on the subject .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Looking up from his letters , with a smile .Miss Hall was only making a general reflection .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: I don ’ t like general reflections at the breakfast table .

div.stage: During the next few speeches the BUTLER and the FOOTMAN come in with covered entrée dishes which they put on the sideboard , coffee and milk in silver pots , and tea . They go out . CLAUDE retires to the window to read his letters .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: I suppose you have prayers at Foley , Helen ?

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: I ’ m afraid I don ’ t . It makes me feel rather shy to read them .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: I don ’ t see why it should . It doesn ’ t make me feel shy .

sp.speaker: MISS HALL
sp.p: You read them so well , Mrs. Insoley .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: I never forget while I ’ m reading them that I ’ m a woman of birth and a woman of property .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: And then I always think the servants hate them .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: The more they hate them , the better it is for them . That is life , my dear Helen . It ’ s a very good thing to begin the day by making it distinctly understood that masters are masters and servants are servants .

sp.speaker: MISS HALL
sp.p: And I think servants like that , Mrs. Insoley .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: It is not a matter of interest to me if they like it or not , Louisa . I have the authority of my maker for it , and that is quite enough for me .

sp.speaker: CENTER
sp.p: HENRY COBBETT comes in .

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: I ’ m sorry I ’ m late .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: When breakfast ’ s at ten o ’ clock I cannot imagine why people shouldn ’ t be punctual .

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: Neither can I .Going to the sideboard .Let ’ s have a look at the food .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: See if there ’ s anything I ’ d like , Louisa .

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: Taking off the covers .There ’ s fried sole — eggs and bacon .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: The staple of every middle-class hotel in the kingdom .

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: And devilled kidneys .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: I ’ ll begin with fried sole , and then I ’ ll have eggs and bacon , Louisa .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Coming forward .Oh , I ’ m sorry . Is there anything I can get you ?

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: Chaffing her fellow-guest .And then , if Mr. Cobbett has left any , perhaps I ’ ll see if I can eat a devilled kidney .

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: With a chuckle .Mr. Cobbett thinks he ’ ll have to look nippy to get anything at all .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: To MISS VERNON .I wonder what I can tempt you with ?

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: I think I ’ ll have some fried sole .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: That ’ s the beauty of the country . One does relish one ’ s breakfast , doesn ’ t one ?

div.stage: He hands a plate to MISS VERNON , and sits down with another for himself . As he does this he takes the Times from under his arm and sits on it .

lg.stage: With a smile at his peculiarity .
lg.l: Is there anything in the Times ,
Claude ?

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: I haven ’ t read it yet .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: In some ways you ’ re much more of a Bainbridge than an Insoley , Claude . My father used always to sit on the Times so that no one should read it before him .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: I must say I don ’ t like to have my paper messed about by a lot of people before I ’ ve had a chance of looking at it . Half the pleasure of reading the Times is reading it first . Besides , the Morning Post and the Mail are on the sideboard for anyone who wants them . EDITH LEWIS comes in .

sp.speaker: EDITH
sp.p: Oh , I know I ’ m dreadfully late . Everybody ’ s going to scold me . And I ’ m so sorry .

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: Imitating MRS. INSOLEY .When breakfast ’ s at ten o ’ clock I cannot imagine why people shouldn ’ t be punctual .

sp.speaker: EDITH
sp.p: Smiling .Isn ’ t Grace down yet ?To CLAUDE , who rises to give her something to eat .No , don ’ t bother . I ’ ll help myself .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: When I was mistress of this house breakfast was served punctually at eight o ’ clock every morning .

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: Flippantly .It must have seemed just like supper . Did you have it the last thing before going to bed ?

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: I made no exceptions . The day after my cousin James broke his neck in the hunting-field and was brought to this very house on a stretcher , I came down as the clock struck . And a very hearty breakfast I ate too .

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: Perhaps he didn ’ t leave you anything .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: With a chuckle .On the contrary , he left me all his debts .

sp.speaker: CENTER
sp.p: Enter GRACE .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Good morning .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: Good afternoon , Grace .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Am I late ? I think punctuality ’ s the most detestable of all the virtues .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: It ’ s a royal virtue , my dear .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: In that case , as a member of the middle classes , it ’ s not surprising that I don ’ t practise it .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: What can I get you , darling ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Is there anything nice to eat ?

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: With a grim smile .That is a matter of opinion .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: There ’ s fried sole and eggs and bacon .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Oh , I don ’ t think I ’ ll have anything . I ’ ll just have some tea and toast .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: My dear , you ’ re not off your feed , are you ?

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: Grace has probably been stuffing herself with bread and butter in her room . I have no patience with the new-fangled custom of giving people tea when they wake up . I never give it to my guests .

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: Then don ’ t ask me to come and stay with you .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: Delighted with the opportunity he has given her .It may surprise you , but I have no intention of doing so .

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: Cheerfully .There now . And I thought I ’ d made such an impression on you , Mrs. Insoley .

lg.l: That ’ s why I couldn ’ t risk asking you to stay with me . Perhaps at my age
I am safe from your blandishments , but Louisa is extremely susceptible .

sp.speaker: MISS HALL
sp.p: Oh , Mrs. Insoley , how can you ! Why , Mr. Cobbett must be ten years younger than I am .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: I should put it at fifteen .

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: Don ’ t dash my hopes to the ground , Miss Hall . I was flattering myself you didn ’ t look upon me altogether with indifference .

div.stage: ARCHIBALD INSOLEY comes in from the garden .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: Ah , I thought I ’ d find you still at breakfast .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: We ’ re a lazy lot . I suppose you ’ ve been up and about for the last two hours .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Looking at him .Is anything the matter ?

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: I thought you looked a bit odd .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: A most awful thing has happened . I ’ ve only just heard of it .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Getting up from his chair .What is it , old man ?

div.stage: By this time the breakfasters are disturbed ; there is a certain embarrassment about them ; they are suffering from the awkwardness people feel when they see some one in a condition of distress , but do not suppose it has anything to do with themselves .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: You ’ d better come along with me to the smoking-room .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: It ’ s too late to make a secret of it , Archibald . You ’ d better tell us all .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Fire away , old man .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: After a moment ’ s hesitation .Peggy Gann has killed herself .

div.stage: GRACE springs to her feet with a cry .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Looking at GRACE .My God .

div.stage: GRACE comes forward , horror on her face , and walks unsteadily to a chair . She sinks into it and stares in front of her .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Why on earth did she do it ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: How horrible !

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Going up to her , about to put his hand on her shoulder .Grace .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: With a shiver .Don ’ t touch me .

div.stage: He stops and looks at her , puzzled and unhappy .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: You ’ d better come along .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: With his eyes on GRACE .I feel I ought to do something . I don ’ t know what to do .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: I ’ m afraid there ’ s nothing much that can be done .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: I ’ d better go and see Gann , hadn ’ t I ?

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: Won ’ t you finish your breakfast before you go , Claude ?

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Oh , I can ’ t eat anything more .

div.stage: He goes out with ARCHIBALD .

sp.speaker: MISS HALL
sp.p: What a dreadful thing .

div.stage: GRACE gets up and goes to the window .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: Where are you going , Grace ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Almost beside herself .For heaven ’ s sake , leave me alone .

div.stage: She stands with her back to the rest of the party , looking out of the window . There is a little awkward pause .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: Louisa , get me some of those devilled kidneys that Mr. Cobbett has been making so much fuss about .

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: Let me .

lg.l: Louisa will get them . She likes to wait on me herself . Don ’ t you ,
Louisa ?

sp.speaker: MISS HALL
sp.p: Yes , Mrs. Insoley .

div.stage: MISS VERNON pushes back her chair .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: Have you finished , Helen ?

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: You ’ ve eaten nothing .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: I couldn ’ t .

div.stage: MISS VERNON looks as if she were going to speak to GRACE , but she changes her mind and merely sits down in another chair . Every now and then she looks up at GRACE .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: I cannot imagine why anyone should be upset because an abandoned hussy has been so wicked as to destroy herself .

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: Well , it hasn ’ t taken my appetite away , at all events .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: If we were honest with ourselves , Mr. Cobbett , we should acknowledge that nobody ’ s death is important enough to interfere with one ’ s appetite .

sp.speaker: MISS HALL
sp.p: Oh , Mrs. Insoley , how can you say such a thing ?

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: Louisa , I ’ ve been like a mother to you for ten years . Would you eat one potato less for your dinner if I were found dead in my bed to-morrow morning ?

sp.speaker: MISS HALL
sp.p: Taking out her handkerchief .Oh , yes , Mrs. Insoley . I really , really would .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: Touched .You are a good girl , Louisa , and you may have that black lace shawl of mine . If you mend it carefully , it ’ ll last you for years .

sp.speaker: MISS HALL
sp.p: Oh , thank you , Mrs. Insoley . You are so kind to me .

sp.speaker: EDITH
sp.p: D ’ you think I ought to offer to go away to-day ? I was going to stay till to-morrow .

lg.l: I was going to-day in any case . I ’ m due to stay with some people in
Wiltshire .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: You seem to be in great demand .

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: I have a very pleasant fund of small talk .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: I ’ m afraid this is not an occasion upon which you ’ ll find it of any use .

div.stage: There is a moment ’ s pause .

sp.speaker: EDITH
sp.p: I ’ m going into the garden .

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: Come on . I ’ m dying for a smoke .

div.stage: She gets up and walks out through the French windows . COBBETT follows her .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: Getting up from the table .I think you should remember , my dear Grace , that suicide is not only very wicked , but very cowardly . I have no patience with the sentimentalities of the present day . Our fathers buried people who were sinful enough to destroy themselves at the cross-roads with a stake in their insides . And it served them right .

div.stage: GRACE does not answer . MRS. INSOLEY , with a shrug of the shoulders , walks out of the room , followed by MISS HALL . As soon as GRACE hears the door shut she turns round with an exclamation , half-smothered , of impatient anger .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Oh , did you hear ? They have the heart to chatter like that when that unhappy girl is lying dead . They haven ’ t a word of pity . It seems to mean nothing to them that she sacrificed herself . If she died , it was to save her father , so that he shouldn ’ t be thrown out of work in his old age . And they call her wicked and sinful .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: But is that anything new to you ? Haven ’ t you noticed that people always rather resent the heroism of others ? They don ’ t like the claim it makes on them , and the easiest way to defend themselves is with a sneer .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I might have saved her life if I ’ d chosen , but I hadn ’ t the courage .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: Afraid that she is going to blurt out a secret which had much better not be referred to .Grace , don ’ t be stupid .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Once I suspected what she was going to do , but she was too clever for me . I so wanted to believe it was all right . I wanted her to go away quietly .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: Trying to calm her .Lots of women have been in difficulties before , and they haven ’ t killed themselves . There must have been some kink in her nature . I suppose the instinct of life wasn ’ t so strong as it is with most of us , and — and she would have committed suicide for almost any reason .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: There was only one thing to say , and I didn ’ t say it . I couldn ’ t .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: My dear , for heaven ’ s sake pull yourself together .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: D ’ you know why Claude was so determined she should go ? Because he couldn ’ t bear that I should come in contact with a woman who ’ d done wrong .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: Looking down .I had an idea that was at the back of his mind .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: With sudden suspicion .Why should you know what Claude feels better than I do ?

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: Fearing she has given herself away .It was a mere guess on my part .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: With a keen look at her .When I asked you the other day whether you ’ d been very much in love with Claude , you wouldn ’ t answer .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: Smiling .I really thought it was no business of yours .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Gravely .Are you in love with him still ?

div.stage: MISS VERNON is about to break out indignantly , but quickly controls herself .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: Yes , I suppose I am .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Much ?

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: Hoarsely . ] Yes .

div.stage: There is a pause .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: D ’ you know that my mother-in-law would give half her fortune to know — what you know ? She ’ s been on the look-out to trip me up for years . It only wants a hint , and she can be trusted to make the most of it .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: My dear , I haven ’ t a notion what you ’ re talking about .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: With a shrug of the shoulders .How did you find out ?

div.stage: MISS VERNON looks at her for a moment , then looks away in embarrassment .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: I suspected before . In those circumstances hardly any men seem able to help a sort of proprietary air . He rather gave it away , you know .... And then yesterday I felt quite certain .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I ’ m in your hands . What are you going to do ?

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: My dear , what can I do ? Claude wouldn ’ t love me more because he loved you less .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: You must utterly despise me .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: No .... I feel awfully sorry for Claude .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Almost jealously .Claude ’ s your first thought always .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: He ’ s been the whole world to me since I was a girl of sixteen .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Is that why you never married ?

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: I suppose it is .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I never dreamt that anyone could care for Claude like that . I suppose you see something in him that I ’ ve never seen .... He has a hundred different ways of getting on my nerves .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: You see , I ’ m not irritated by the mannerisms that irritate you .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Reflectively .Real love accepts them , I suppose .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: It wants them even because it ’ s something individual to cling to .... And then it laughs at them a little , and the best love of all includes a sense of humour .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: It ’ s made me feel so strange to know that you love him , Helen . It ’ s given him something that he ’ s never had before .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: I don ’ t suppose any woman likes her husband less because she knows that another woman is eating her heart out for him .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Slowly .I wonder if I ’ ve misjudged him all these years .... D ’ you think I found him shallow because there was no depth in me , and narrow because I was narrow myself .

div.stage: Enter CLAUDE INSOLEY . GRACE turns to him quickly .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Did you see Gann ?

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Touching the bell .No , he wasn ’ t at the cottage . I ’ ve sent for him and told him to come here .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: They know where he is then ?

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Yes , worse luck . He ’ s been soaking at the public-house since it opened .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: But when did it happen ?

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Peggy , d ’ you mean ? She did it last night .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Last night ? But why have we only just heard of it ?

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Deeply discouraged .Because they don ’ t come to us any more when they ’ re in trouble . They keep it to themselves .

div.stage: MOORE answers the bell .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Oh , Moore , when Gann comes let me know . I ’ ll come and see him at once .

sp.speaker: MOORE
sp.p: He ’ s here now , sir .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Is he ? I didn ’ t expect him yet . All right .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Won ’ t you let him come here , Claude ? I should like to speak to him too .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: I don ’ t think you ’ d better see him if he ’ s been drinking . He may be going to make himself rather objectionable .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I must say to him what I ’ ve got on my heart , Claude .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Very well .To MOORE .Tell Gann to come here .

sp.speaker: MOORE
sp.p: Very good , sir .

div.stage: Exit .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: I dare say you ’ d like me to leave you .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: You don ’ t mind , do you ?

div.stage: With a shake of the head and a smile MISS VERNON goes out . CLAUDE looks a little uncertainly at his wife . He seeks for something to say .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: What a nice woman that is ! I can ’ t imagine why Archibald doesn ’ t hurry up and marry her .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Perhaps he ’ s not in love with her .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Any man in his senses would be in love with her .

div.stage: GRACE does not answer , but she gives him a curious glance . MOORE opens the door to show GANN in . GANN is dishevelled and untidy , his face haggard and drawn . He is not exactly drunk , but he is stupefied , partly with liquor and partly with grief . He carries his gun . He comes in , his cap on his head , and stands clumsily near the door .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Take off your cap , Gann .

div.stage: GANN looks at him unsteadily and slowly takes off his cap .

sp.speaker: GANN
sp.p: Did you want to speak to me , Squire ?

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: I ’ ve just been round to your cottage , Gann . I saw Peggy .... I want to tell you how awfully sorry I am for what ’ s happened . I can never forgive myself .

div.stage: GANN steps forward with a lurch and faces CLAUDE .

sp.speaker: GANN
sp.p: What d ’ you want me for ? Couldn ’ t you let me be ? D ’ you still want me to go ?

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: No . That ’ s what I wanted to tell you .

sp.speaker: GANN
sp.p: Give us time and we ’ ll clear . We don ’ t want long . Give us time to bury the girl . That ’ s all we want .

div.stage: GRACE gives an exclamation of horror .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: I hope you ’ ll stay . I want to do everything I can to make up for your loss . I want you to know that I blame myself most awfully .

sp.speaker: GANN
sp.p: Will that bring ’ er back to life , d ’ you think ?

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: I ’ d give anything for this horrible accident not to have happened .With a look at Grace .I ’ m afraid it ’ s my fault .

sp.speaker: GANN
sp.p: She killed ’ erself so as I shouldn ’ t be turned off . That ’ s why she killed ’ erself . You ’ re a hard master — you always was . She thought it was the only way to save me from the work ’ us .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Very awkwardly .In future I ’ ll try to be different . I didn ’ t think I was hard . I thought I was only just .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: It was a cruel rule .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: I thought I was only doing my duty .

sp.speaker: GANN
sp.p: She was a good girl , after all , Squire , a good girl .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: I ’ m sure she was .

sp.speaker: GANN
sp.p: It ’ s easy enough for you people to keep straight . You don ’ t ’ ave temptations like we ’ ave .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: No , that ’ s true enough . I suppose it ’ s not really very hard for us to be moderately decent .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: In a choking voice .Where is the child now , Gann ?

sp.speaker: GANN
sp.p: Violently .D ’ you want that too ? Ain ’ t you satisfied yet ? Has the child got to go before I stay ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: No , no . I only wanted to know if there was anything I could do . I wanted to help you .

sp.speaker: GANN
sp.p: I don ’ t want your ’ elp . I only want you to let me work and earn my wages .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: That you shall do , I promise you .

sp.speaker: GANN
sp.p: Can I go now ? I ’ ve got a deal to do this morning .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Yes .... Will you shake hands with me before you go ?

sp.speaker: GANN
sp.p: What good ’ ll that do you ?

div.stage: CLAUDE gives a gesture of discouragement .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: I can only repeat that I ’ m most awfully sorry . I ’ m afraid there ’ s absolutely nothing I can do to make up for your great loss .... You can go now .

div.stage: GANN turns to go , while CLAUDE and GRACE watch him silently . Suddenly he comes back and thrusts his gun into CLAUDE ’ S hand .

sp.speaker: GANN
sp.p: Look ’ ere , Squire , you take my gun . I ain ’ t fit to keep it .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Sharply .What the devil d ’ you mean ?

sp.speaker: GANN
sp.p: Last night when the liquor was in me I swore I ’ d blow your brains out and swing for it . Don ’ t let me ’ ave the gun . I ’ m not fit to keep it yet . If I get on the drink again I ’ ll kill you .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: What the dickens d ’ you mean by speaking to me like that ! Of course you must have your gun . I can ’ t allow you to neglect your work .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Almost in a whisper .Claude , take care .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Looking at the lock .Why isn ’ t it loaded ?

sp.speaker: GANN
sp.p: They took the cartridges out . I was about mad , and I don ’ t know what I said . If I ’ d come across you then — you wouldn ’ t be standing where you are now .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: I suppose you take eights ?

div.stage: GRACE and GANN both look at him . GRACE gives a start when she realises what he is going to do .

sp.speaker: GANN
sp.p: That ’ s right .

div.stage: CLAUDE nods and goes to the door . He hesitates , with a look at GRACE .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I shall be all right .

div.stage: He goes out . In a moment he comes back with two cartridges . He puts them in the gun , and hands it back to the gamekeeper .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Here you are . I don ’ t think I ’ m afraid . I ’ ll take my chance of your wanting to shoot me .

div.stage: GANN takes the gun , and his hands close round it convulsively . He half raises it . CLAUDE goes to the door through which he has just come , and closes it . Then , almost mastered by the temptation , GANN pulls himself together and advances a step towards his master . GRACE gives a stifled cry . CLAUDE turns round and faces the man .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: That ’ ll do , Gann . I don ’ t think I have anything more to say to you . You can go .

div.stage: GANN struggles to command himself . His fingers itch to shoot , but CLAUDE ’ S unconcern prevents him .

sp.speaker: GANN
sp.p: By God !

div.stage: He turns round to go , and flings the gun violently from him .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Peremptorily .Gann , take your gun .

div.stage: The man stops , looks at his master , and then , cowed , picks it up . He lurches heavily out of the room . There is a pause . GRACE draws a long breath .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I ’ m glad you did that , Claude .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Thinking she refers to his attempts at apology .It was very difficult to know what to say to him .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I didn ’ t mean that . I meant , I ’ m glad you made him take the gun .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Oh ! Hang it all , you didn ’ t think I was likely to be frightened of one of my own servants , did you ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: In a low voice .I was rather afraid he was going to shoot you .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: So was I . But I felt pretty sure he saw two of me , and I thought he ’ d probably shoot at the wrong one .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: You ’ re very plucky .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Rot !He hesitates for a moment .Grace , I ’ m afraid you think I ’ ve been an awful skunk .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: With a quick look at him .We none of us knew anything like this was going to happen .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Will you forgive me ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Startled .I ?

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: I ’ ve been feeling such an awful cad . If I ’ d only done what you wanted me to , this wouldn ’ t have happened .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: That ’ s not your fault . I didn ’ t say — what I should have said to make you change your mind .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: It rather put my back up that you should be so set on letting Peggy stay . But it struck me afterwards , of course you couldn ’ t feel the same about it as I did . I think if one ’ s awfully straight , one ’ s full of charity , don ’ t you know .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: My dear Claude , you talk as if I were a girl of eighteen .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: I don ’ t suppose you remember , but when Archibald told us , I wanted to say something to you ....

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Yes , your first thought was for me , wasn ’ t it ?

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Going on .And I came near you . And — and you sort of shuddered , and said : “ For God ’ s sake , don ’ t touch me !”

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I ’ m sorry . I didn ’ t mean to be unkind .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: No , I know you didn ’ t . It just came out unawares . And — oh , Grace , I couldn ’ t bear to think you — you couldn ’ t stick me , don ’ t you know .... I suppose I ’ m a damned fool , but I haven ’ t made you hate and loathe me , have I ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I ’ m not worth so much troubling about , Claude .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: I can ’ t help it . You ’ ve just somehow got in my blood and bones , and if it didn ’ t sound such drivel , I ’ d say you meant everything in the world to me . Only you just laugh at me when I say things like that .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Explaining to herself rather than to him .It ’ s very hard for all of us to say what we mean . The words we use are so frayed . One ought to guess at — at the soul within them .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: I ’ ve been trying to think about Gann and his daughter , but I can ’ t really think of anything but you .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: You know , Claude , no one ’ s so wonderful as you think me . I ’ m no longer so young as all that , and you ’ re the only person who ever thought me very pretty .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: I don ’ t mind . Sometimes , so that my love should mean more to you , don ’ t you know , I ’ ve wanted you to get older quickly , and I ’ ve wanted you to be plain .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: With a little hysterical laugh .Oh , my dear , what a horrible prospect .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Don ’ t laugh at me now , Grace .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: With tears in her voice .I ’ m not laughing at you . God knows I ’ m not laughing at you .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: I ’ m such an ass at explaining myself . What I want to make you understand is that I don ’ t love you for anything that other people could love you for . I love you because you ’ re you , don ’ t you know . Because you ’ re so awfully good and straight . And you know I respect you so awfully .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: In a hoarse voice .I ’ m not good , Claude .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: If I didn ’ t believe it , I should think the world a pretty rotten place .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I haven ’ t been the sort of wife you wanted . I felt that always .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: You ’ ve been the only woman in the world for me . Always .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Deeply moved .Not many women can say that , can they ? One ought to be very grateful .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: D ’ you remember the first time I ever saw you ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Looking away from him .I wonder you didn ’ t marry Helen Vernon years before you came across me .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Hang it all , why on earth should I have done that !

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Your mother was very anxious that you should .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: I was just as little in love with Helen Vernon as she was in love with me .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I can ’ t help seeing that she would have made you a much better wife than I have . She would have understood you . I don ’ t think I ever understood you . I ’ ve been a wretched failure , Claude .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Darling , how can you talk such rot ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: She might have had children . You wanted them so much , Claude , and I haven ’ t given you any .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: That ’ s been hard luck on both of us , darling .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: With deep feeling .It might have made all the difference .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: If I wanted children it was chiefly because I thought you ’ d be happier . You wouldn ’ t have minded the dull life down here then . And you might have cared a bit more for me because I was their father .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: It all comes back to me , doesn ’ t it ? I ’ m in all your thoughts always .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: D ’ you mind ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I ’ m so ashamed .

div.stage: ARCHIBALD comes in from the hall .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: Oh , Claude , I met the coroner ’ s officer on my way along here . He wants to see you .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: All right . I ’ ll come . Is he in the hall ?

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: With a nod .I told him you knew nothing more than I ’ d said . But I ’ m afraid they ’ ll call you at the inquest .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: The only thing ’ s to grin and bear it .

div.stage: They go out . GRACE sinks into a chair at the writing-table and buries her face in her hands . In a moment HENRY COBBETT enters . She starts up when she hears his footstep on the gravel . He has his hat in his hand and his coat over his arm .

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: I ’ m just starting . I was looking for you to say good-bye .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Is it time for you to go already ? I didn ’ t know it was late .

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: Thanks awfully for putting me up . It ’ s been perfectly topping .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: It was nice of you to come . I hope you ’ ll run down again one of these days .

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: In a lower tone .I suppose you never want to set eyes on me again .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Never .

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: You ’ re not awfully unhappy , are you ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: With something between a sob and a chuckle .Awfully .

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: I ’ m dreadfully sorry .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: That doesn ’ t do me much good , does it ?

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: If there ’ s anything I can do , I ’ d like awfully to do it if you ’ d let me .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: No , whatever happens no one can help me but myself .

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: I shouldn ’ t have played the fool if I ’ d thought you were going to take things so much to heart .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Ironically .That ’ s the nuisance of women , isn ’ t it ? They will make an affair of what ’ s really only an episode .

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: You have a way of saying things that makes one feel an awful bounder . After all , one can ’ t help falling in love , and one ’ s not a blackguard because one falls out of it .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: D ’ you remember asking me yesterday if I was beginning to care for Claude differently ?

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I love him as I never thought it was possible to love . I don ’ t know why I love him . It ’ s come to me suddenly . I — oh , I can ’ t tell you what it is . It ’ s like hunger in my soul . And I ’ m frightened .

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: I should have thought that made everything all right .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: It ’ s come too late . I ’ m — soiled . Afterwards — you know what I mean , when you and I — the first thing I felt was surprise because I found myself no different . I thought when a woman had done that everything would seem altered . But I felt just the same as before . It ’ s only now . It ’ s like the stain of blood — don ’ t you remember — not all the perfumes of Arabia ....

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: Worried and moved .You know , it ’ s absurd to take it like that .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: With increasing agitation .Oh , what have I done ! If I ’ d only had the strength to resist ! It ’ s now that I see it all , the utter degradation of it , the hateful ugliness . Oh , I loathe myself . How can I take my heart to Claude when there ’ s you standing between us ?

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: I ’ m awfully sorry , Grace .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I ’ d give anything in the world if I hadn ’ t done what I have done . I might be so happy now . I haven ’ t a chance . The fates are against me . What ’ s the good of loving Claude now — I ’ m not fit to be his wife .

div.stage: She is beside herself . COBBETT , not knowing what to do , stands looking at her . The sound is heard of a motor-horn blowing .

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: With a slight start .What ’ s that ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: It ’ s Rooney . He ’ s afraid you ’ ll miss the train . You ’ d better hurry up .

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: I can ’ t leave you like this .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Ironically .I shouldn ’ t like you to miss your train .

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: I suppose you hate and loathe me .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I ’ d wish you were dead , only it wouldn ’ t do me much good , would it ?

sp.speaker: COBBETT
sp.p: Reflectively .The fact is , only the wicked should sin .... When the virtuous do things they shouldn ’ t they do make such an awful hash of it .

div.stage: MOORE comes in followed by the FOOTMAN .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: What is it ?

sp.speaker: MOORE
sp.p: I was going to clear away , madam .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Oh , yes , I forgot .Holding out her hand to COBBETT .You ’ ll have to look sharp . END OF THE THIRD ACT

div.head: THE FOURTH ACT

stage.stage: THE SCENE is the same as in the first and second Acts , the drawing-room at Kenyon-Fulton .
Two days have elapsed . It is about twelve o ’ clock in the morning . MRS. INSOLEY is seated with her dog on her lap , and MISS HALL is reading the leading article of the Times to her .

sp.speaker: MISS HALL
sp.p: Reading .“ ... to whom it would give the suffrage are marked off from all citizens who have ever and anywhere enjoyed the franchise in great civil communities by physical differences which no legislation can affect . Women , they insist , pay rates and taxes as men do , and therefore , they argue , women ought to vote as men do . But rates and taxes may be imposed or abolished by legislation . Men may become ratepayers and taxpayers , or cease to be ratepayers and taxpayers . The one thing that no enthusiasm , no reasoning , no eloquence , demonstrations , or statutes can achieve is to make a woman a man .”

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: How true that is , Louisa .

sp.speaker: MISS HALL
sp.p: I ’ ve always thought exactly the same myself , Mrs. Insoley .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: And there ’ s another thing , Louisa . No man can become a mother .

sp.speaker: MISS HALL
sp.p: Reflectively .No , I suppose not .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: Have you any doubts on the subject , Louisa ?

sp.speaker: MISS HALL
sp.p: Oh , no , Mrs. Insoley .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: Ironically .You may take it from me that no man can become a mother . And apparently very few women either nowadays .

div.stage: ARCHIBALD INSOLEY comes in .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: Good morning , mother .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: Good morning , my dear .

div.stage: He bends down and kisses her .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: Good morning , Miss Hall .

sp.speaker: MISS HALL
sp.p: Good morning .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: Louisa , you may read the rest of that article to yourself in the garden .

sp.speaker: MISS HALL
sp.p: Getting up .Very well , Mrs. Insoley . Shall I take the dog ?

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: Handing it over .Yes . And be very careful with him . He says he ’ s not very well to-day .

div.stage: MISS HALL takes the dog and goes out .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: I ’ m glad to have an opportunity of talking to you , Archibald . I ’ ve fancied that you ’ ve been rather avoiding me the last day or two .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: Cheerfully .Oh , no , my dear mother .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: When I asked Grace to invite Helen Vernon to stay here for a few days , it was in the confident hope that you would make her a proposal of marriage .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: I respect and esteem Miss Vernon , but I confess that no warmer feeling has ever entered my bosom .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: It ’ s not necessary that warm feelings should enter a clergyman ’ s bosom , Archibald . She ’ s of very good family indeed , and an heiress . Five thousand acres and a house that ’ s only just been done up .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: With a chuckle .If there only weren ’ t a wife to be taken along with the property !

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: With a twinkle in her eyes .It shouldn ’ t be necessary for me to tell a person of your profession that none of the pleasures of this world can be had without some drawback .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: What a pity it is you weren ’ t a man , mother . You would have made such a bishop .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: Are you trying to change the conversation , Archibald ?

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: I don ’ t think it would be a bad idea .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: Then I will only say one thing more . I am the meekest woman in the world , and a lamb could lead me . But I should like to remind you that the living of Kenyon-Fulton is not worth more than a hundred and seventy a year , and if you can keep a curate and live like a gentleman it ’ s only owing to my generosity .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: I ’ m quite prepared to live on a hundred and seventy a year , mother . I dare say it would have just as good an effect on my figure as matrimony .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: Rather crossly .I don ’ t know what you ’ re talking about , Archibald .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: I understood you to recommend marriage as a sort of heroic remedy for corpulence .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: You have nothing against Helen , I presume ?

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: Smiling .I could have wished that fewer summers had passed over a fringe which I shrewdly suspect to be artificial .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: Of course it ’ s artificial , but you ’ re no chicken yourself , Archibald .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: On the contrary , I ’ m much too old a bird to be caught by chaff .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: I ’ m sure we don ’ t want another flighty young thing in the family .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: I don ’ t think Grace has been very flighty the last day or two .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: What ’ s the matter with her ? She ’ s been going about with a face as long as one of your sermons .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: I ’ m afraid Peggy ’ s death upset her very much .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: Irritably .That ’ s the worst of those sort of people , they have no self-control . If she ’ s going to give way like this at the death of a kitchen-maid , what on earth is she going to do at the death of a duchess ?

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: Is it a riddle , mother ?

div.stage: GRACE comes in . She looks tired and worn . She is in a very nervous state . She gives the impression that any folly , any wildness may be expected from her .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Good morning , Archibald .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: Good morning .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I thought you ’ d be at the inquest .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: No . There was no need for me to go . And Claude seemed to think he ’ d rather I didn ’ t .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: What is this ?

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: The inquest on Peggy Gann .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Have you seen Claude ?

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: He looked in at the Rectory for five minutes . I ’ m afraid he ’ s awfully worried .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: I have no patience with Claude . He should have more self-respect than to let such a thing worry him .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: He ’ s afraid he may be asked some very unpleasant questions .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: You seem entirely to forget the relative positions of the parties concerned . If Claude doesn ’ t want to answer an impertinent question , it ’ s the easiest thing in the world for him to fly into a passion and refuse . Who is the coroner ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: His name is Davies . He ’ s the local doctor .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: You ’ re not going to suggest that the local doctor would dream of asking a question unless he was quite sure Claude was prepared to answer it ?

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: Davies is an advanced Radical . I ’ m afraid he may take the opportunity to have a fling at Claude .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: I ’ m all at sea . In my day we wouldn ’ t have stood a doctor for five minutes who was a Radical . We ’ d have made life unbearable for him until he became a Conservative or left the district .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: With a shrug of the shoulders .You ’ re looking rather dicky , Grace .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Oh , I ’ m quite well , thank you .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: Am I mistaken in thinking you have rouge on your cheeks ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I ’ ve not been sleeping very well , and I didn ’ t want to look ill .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: In my young days ladies did not paint their faces .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: With suppressed rage .We don ’ t live in your young days , and I ’ m not a lady .

sp.speaker: MRS. INSOLEY
sp.p: With a chuckle at the opportunity GRACE has given her .As you are my hostess , it would be insolent of me to contradict you , my dear Grace .

div.stage: Delighted with her repartee , she gets up and walks out of the room . GRACE goes up to the looking-glass over the chimney-piece and rubs her cheeks with a handkerchief .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: I wonder if you ’ d be very angry if I said something to you ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Icily .Do you object to the way I do my hair , or is it the cut of my skirt that doesn ’ t quite meet with your approval ?

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: I was going to say something to you about Claude .

div.stage: GRACE gives a slight , an almost imperceptible start , but does not answer or look round .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: You know how funny he is . He doesn ’ t say much when anything ’ s on his mind . But if one knows him well it ’ s not hard to tell when something ’ s bothering him .... He ’ s awfully worried about you .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Still looking in the glass .I don ’ t know why I should worry him now more than I usually do .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: He ’ s afraid you blame him for Peggy ’ s death .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Why should I ?

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: He feels it was his fault .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I suppose it was in a way .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: He ’ s so fond of you he can ’ t bear to think that — that it ’ s made a difference to you .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Has he said anything to you about it ?

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Perhaps it ’ s only your fancy .Turning round .Why are you telling me now ?

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: I ’ m afraid he ’ ll have rather a rough time at the inquest . I thought you might say something to buck him up a little . A word or two from you would mean so much .

div.stage: There is a short pause .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I think it ’ s so strange that you should say all this to me now . It ’ s not as if we ’ d ever been great friends , is it ?

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: Our best friends are always those who put us in a good conceit of ourselves . I always think it ’ s a dreadful thing when a man loses his nerve .... You can do so much for Claude if you choose .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I think you exaggerate the influence I have over him . After all , he ’ s always taken care to keep me and his life strictly apart .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: I think you should remember that if he made a mistake it was an honest one . He wouldn ’ t be human if he didn ’ t put his foot in it sometimes .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: You speak as if I were perfection itself .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: And then , if he was so determined not to break that particular rule of the estate , it was partly for your sake , wasn ’ t it ? Because he thought it his duty to keep you from any possibility of contact with evil .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Did he tell you that ?

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: No . It was not very difficult to guess .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I suppose not — for anyone who had eyes to see .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: You will do your best , Grace ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: What do you suggest I should do ?

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: It ’ s very difficult for me to tell you . I think the chief thing is that you should tell Claude — if you can — that you ’ re fond of him , and that , whatever happens , you always will be fond of him .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Hoarsely .That oughtn ’ t to be very hard . I love him with all my heart and soul .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: Smiling .If you could only say that to him — just in that way , as if you really felt it — you would make him so happy .

div.stage: There is a pause . GRACE puts her hands in front of her eyes , and she keeps them there for a moment so that she should not see ARCHIBALD while she is speaking .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Archibald , I want to speak to you for a minute — as a clergyman .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: My dear Grace , you frighten me .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I ’ m sorry if I ’ ve been often bitter and unkind to you . I ’ m ashamed when I think of all the silly , cruel things I must have said to you during the ten years I ’ ve lived here .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: Cheerfully .Oh , what nonsense ! You ’ ve got a clever tongue , and like most people who have , you can ’ t resist saying a sharp thing when it strikes you .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I ’ ve often set out to wound you . I ’ ve been fiendish sometimes . I ’ d like you to know that I ’ m grateful to you for being so patient with me . It wouldn ’ t be surprising if you loathed me .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: Oh , I think I ’ ve always had a very great affection for you , Grace . I know you ’ ve often found life down here rather dull . If any allowances have been necessary , I ’ ve been perfectly ready to make them .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I expect I was often unjust to you . I sometimes felt you weren ’ t quite sincere .... I thought you ’ d only become a clergyman on account of the living and the house .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: Yes , I felt that . But I couldn ’ t bear you any ill-will on that account . It was true .

div.stage: GRACE turns and looks at him with startled eyes .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: I ’ m afraid I ’ m not much in the way of parsons . My class means so much more to me than my calling . I know it ’ s a mistake , and yet I can ’ t help it . I ’ m bound down by conventions that I haven ’ t the will to escape from . The day ’ s past of the family living , the perquisite of a younger son , and I ’ m out of place here . I can ’ t feel that the position is mine by right as my Uncle Robert felt before me , and I haven ’ t the enthusiasm which might make me feel I ’ d earned it by my own efforts .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I ’ m so ashamed of myself . Because people didn ’ t carry their hearts on their sleeves I thought they had no hearts at all .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: For three years after I was ordained I was a curate at Wakefield . I was worked so hard that I never had a moment to myself . I think those were my happy days . And that ’ s what I ought to do now . I ought to exchange all this for some living in a city , and do some real work before it ’ s too late . But I haven ’ t the courage . And then I should do no good , for I haven ’ t conviction . That ’ s why I have no influence in the parish . They come to me for beef-tea and for coal-tickets , but when it ’ s real help they want they go elsewhere . All I ’ m fit for is to hold a family living and dine with the neighbouring gentry . You summed me up with the utmost precision .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I don ’ t think so any more . I have an idea that perhaps one sees people most truly when one sees them charitably .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: With a smile .You said you wanted to speak to me , and I ’ ve been talking only about myself .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I think you ’ ve made it a little easier for me , Archibald . It ’ s kind of you .

div.stage: She pauses and there is a silence . She walks up and down the room in agitation .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: With a series of little gasps .Archibald , I ’ m dreadfully unhappy . I ’ ve done something which I bitterly regret . I don ’ t know how to tell you . But I must tell you .... I ’ ve been unfaithful to Claude .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: Grace , you must be mad . You can ’ t mean what you say . It ’ s — it ’ s impossible .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: It ’ s torturing me . It ’ s torturing me .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: But I don ’ t understand . You don ’ t mean that ....

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Desperately .Oh , yes , I mean exactly what I say . Please understand me .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: You said you were in love with Claude .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Yes . That ’ s why I can ’ t bear the agony of it . I ’ m so unhappy . I ’ m so dreadfully unhappy . I want you to help me . I want you to tell me what to do .

div.stage: There is a moment ’ s pause . ARCHIBALD is so bewildered that he can find not a word to say .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: You can hardly believe it , can you ? It sounds incredible . Sometimes I can ’ t help saying to myself that it is not possible it should be true .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: Trying to collect himself .It ’ s come as a most dreadful blow .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Don ’ t reproach me . I ’ ve said all the obvious things to myself already .... Oh , I hate myself .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: I ’ m so bewildered . Why d ’ you tell me ? I feel I ought to ask you all sorts of questions , and I can ’ t bear to ask you anything .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I don ’ t think anything matters but that I ’ ve behaved odiously . Claude was always very good to me , and I ’ ve deceived him . And every kindness , every word of love he says to me is a reproach . And I love him with all my soul , and there ’ s always the horror of what I ’ ve done between us . And I can ’ t bear it any longer .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: I ’ m so helpless .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Are you going to tell Claude ?

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: I ? You must be mad .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I thought perhaps you might feel it was your duty . You ’ re his brother .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: It would never occur to me to betray the confidence you ’ ve put in me .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Then what shall I do ?

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: I can ’ t advise you . I haven ’ t got the experience . I know so little of the world .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: You must advise me . I ’ m at the end of my strength . I can ’ t go on like this any more .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: Is it all over between you and ... you know what I mean ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Yes , it ’ s all over .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: I don ’ t know what to say to you . I ’ m awfully sorry .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Desperately .Is there no one who can do anything for me ?

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: I suppose nobody else knows ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Helen Vernon . She found out . But I can ’ t go to her for advice . I can ’ t . I can ’ t humiliate myself . And the remorse is just killing me .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: It ’ s so difficult for me to say things that won ’ t seem sanctimonious . I don ’ t want to say a word that you can think is a reproach .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I don ’ t mind what you say so long as you help me .

div.stage: There is a moment ’ s pause .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: Hesitatingly .We ’ re taught that there ’ s one course clear to the sinner that repenteth .

div.stage: GRACE starts to her feet and looks at him wildly .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: You want me to tell Claude ?

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: In a low voice .I don ’ t see how there can be forgiveness till one has confessed one ’ s sin .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: With a deep , deep sigh .Oh , if you knew what a relief it would be ! For days I ’ ve been fighting with the temptation to make a clean breast of it . I ’ ve been trying to keep it from me , trying not to think of it . But it meets me at every turn . It haunts me . It ’ s like an obsession , and it ’ s stronger than I am . It ’ s driving me — driving me to confess . I know I shall have to do it ; I can ’ t help myself . I shall go mad if I don ’ t tell him .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: For goodness ’ sake , calm yourself .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: If I ’ d told him before , when I was trying to persuade him to let Gann stay , that girl wouldn ’ t have died . I hadn ’ t the courage . I wouldn ’ t sacrifice myself . It was too much to ask me . And since then I ’ ve been tortured by remorse . They say she had the suicidal instinct , and would have killed herself for almost anything . But I seem to see her lying there reproaching me . Reproaching me .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: Why don ’ t you go to Claude at once and get it over ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I ’ m frightened . I ’ m just sick with fear . A dozen times I ’ ve been on the point of it — just to have done with it , to get rid of the agony that burnt my heart — and at the last moment I couldn ’ t . But it ’ s like being on a high place and looking down and holding on to something so that you shouldn ’ t throw yourself over . Sooner or later I shall have to do it . It ’ s the only way to get back my self-respect . It ’ s the only chance I have of living at all .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: I wish I could do more for you .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: No one can do anything for me . Oh , it is cruel . And to come just now when I love Claude ! I didn ’ t love him at first . It came quite suddenly — as if scales had been torn away from my eyes . And it wasn ’ t till then that I saw the sin and the wickedness of it . Oh , it was so much more than sin and wickedness . The filthiness . The only thing ’ s to tell him and have done with it . You know he ’ ll divorce me , don ’ t you ?

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: He loves you so much .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Even if it breaks his heart , he ’ ll force himself to divorce me . You know what Claude is . He ’ ll think it ’ s his duty . He ’ ll do what he thinks he ought to do even if it kills him . Oh , but if he ’ d only forgive me , I would try to make amends . It ’ s so hard that I ’ ve only learnt how to be a good wife now that I ’ m unfit to be his wife at all .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: Deeply moved .Be brave , Grace .

div.stage: She looks at him for a moment , then suddenly makes up her mind . She takes a letter from her dress and sits down at the desk . She puts it into an envelope on which she writes CLAUDE ’ S name .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Will you ring the bell ?

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: Touching it .What are you going to do ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: It ’ s a letter that I had from — the other . It ’ s proof of everything . I felt I couldn ’ t tell Claude . It was hopeless . And I thought I ’ d just press it into his hand ....

div.stage: As she is speaking MOORE comes in . She hands him the letter .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Have that given to Mr. Insoley the moment he comes in .

sp.speaker: MOORE
sp.p: Very good , madam .

div.stage: Exit .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: Startled .D ’ you mean to say you ’ re going to tell him like that ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: It ’ s the only way I can do it .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: Overcome .Good God , what have I done ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: He ’ ll read the letter , and then the worst will be over . I couldn ’ t have told him — I couldn ’ t .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: I hope you ’ ve done right .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Anyhow , it ’ s the end of everything — just when I might have started a new life .... I wonder when I shall have to go away from here ?

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: Don ’ t put it like that .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Looking out of the window .I thought I hated the place . It ’ s bored me to the verge of tears . And now I shall never again see the night fall on the park slowly . And I feel ... and I feel that with me , too , those great trees , and the meadows , and the cawing rooks have come to be part of my blood and my bones .

div.stage: The door is opened , and GRACE gives a start and a little frightened cry . HELEN VERNON comes in .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Oh , I thought it was Claude .

div.stage: She puts her hand to her heart and steadies herself against a chair .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: What on earth ’ s the matter ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: With a gesture of the head towards ARCHIBALD .I ’ ve told him about me and ....

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: In short exclamation , which does not interrupt GRACE .Oh !

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I ’ m going to tell Claude . It ’ s the only thing to do .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: To ARCHIBALD , sharply .Is that your advice ? You fool , Archibald !

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I can ’ t bear the torture any more .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: I suspected you were thinking of something like this . But you wouldn ’ t let me speak to you .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I ’ ve been struggling against it , and now I ’ ve made up my mind .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: My dear , there are three good rules in life . The first is — never sin ; and that ’ s the most sensible . The second is — if you sin , never repent ; and that ’ s the bravest . But the third is — if you repent , never never confess ; and that ’ s the hardest of them all .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: I don ’ t think this is the time for flippancy , Helen .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: Good heavens , I ’ m being as serious as I possibly can .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: D ’ you mean to say you think Grace oughtn ’ t to say anything ?

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: I think it would be monstrous of her to say anything .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: If the sinner wants forgiveness , first of all he must confess his sin .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: You still look upon your God as a God of vengeance , who wants sacrifices to appease Him .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: “ If we confess our sins , He is faithful and just to forgive us our sins .”

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: That was said to a stiff-necked generation that wanted humbling . But no one can want to humble us , surely . We ’ re so timid already . We ’ re so unsure of ourselves . We ’ ve all got a morbid desire to unbosom ourselves . The commonest ailment of the day is a vulgar feminine passion for making scenes . Confession ’ s like a drug we fly to because we ’ ve lost the last shadow of our self-reliance .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: Don ’ t let her move you , Grace . I beseech you , for your soul ’ s sake . Be brave .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I know that it ’ s my only chance of happiness .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: But who cares about your happiness ?

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: Helen , how can you be so unkind ?

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: No one knows why we ’ ve been brought into the world , but it evidently wasn ’ t for our happiness . Or if it was , the Being who put us here has made a most outrageous mess of it . Put your happiness out of the question .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: Very earnestly to GRACE .If the sinner repents , let him confess his sin . That ’ s the only proof he can give of a contrite spirit .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: Nonsense . He can give a much more sensible proof by acting differently in future .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: That would be so easy now .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: But actions aren ’ t good because they ’ re difficult .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Part of my punishment is the feeling that except for this horrible mistake we should both be so much happier than we were before .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: You love Claude now , don ’ t you ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: With all my heart .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: I have an idea that it ’ s only your sin that has made your love worth having .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: Rather shocked .Helen .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: You were rather hard and selfish before because you had nothing in particular to reproach yourself with . Perhaps it was necessary that you should step from the narrow path of virtue in order to become a virtuous woman .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: Helen , you can ’ t mean that .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: It ’ s very often only repentance that makes men and women human .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: Repentance is useless without sacrifice .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Yes , I feel that . And the only sacrifice I can make is to lay bare my soul before Claude and accept my punishment .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: And then , I think Claude should be given the chance of deciding for himself . It ’ s not fair to leave him in ignorance .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: To GRACE .Don ’ t you know that Claude loves you , and trusts you , and believes in you ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: That is all my torment . I ’ m so unworthy . If I didn ’ t love him — if I didn ’ t want him to love me so much — it wouldn ’ t be so dreadful .... I can ’ t bear that there should be this secret between us . I know that he ’ s not loving me , but some fancy of his own heart . And I ’ m jealous . I ’ m jealous of the woman he loves who isn ’ t me . And I want him to love me as I am , as I love him .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: Grace , don ’ t forget that I ’ ve loved him , too , hopelessly , without any thought of a return . It gives me some claim , doesn ’ t it ?

div.stage: ARCHIBALD looks at her quickly , with surprise , but does not speak .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: The only thing I care for is his happiness . And I beseech you to have mercy on him .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: What do you mean ?

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: If you destroy his belief in you he ’ ll have nothing left . He thinks he ’ s strong , but he isn ’ t . He depends on a few simple principles , and some of them are already giving way under his feet . He wants you now more than ever . You can give him back his self-reliance . And you ’ re going to humiliate him . Besides everything else , the misery and the grief , don ’ t you see what a blow it ’ ll be to his vanity ? I beseech you to have mercy .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: You ’ re asking me to go on living the hateful lie . But I can ’ t breathe . The air about me seems heavy with deceit . If Claude doesn ’ t love me for what I am , what can his love be to me ?

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: My dear , it ’ s not for ourselves that our friends love us , but for the grace and the beauty that they ’ ve given us out of their own hearts . And the only way we can show them our gratitude is by doing all we can to preserve those precious illusions they have about us .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I don ’ t want a love that ’ s based on illusion . At the back of my mind there was the hope that if I told Claude , some day in the future he might forgive me . And we could start fresh with mutual knowledge and mutual confidence . But if I don ’ t tell him , we can never come together . Even though we ’ re not separated for an hour , there ’ ll always be this barrier between us .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: Then let that be your punishment .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Startled .That !With a little laugh of scorn .You don ’ t know what you ’ re asking me to do . It ’ s because I love Claude so much that I can ’ t let him go on thinking I ’ m good and pure and chaste .

sp.speaker: ARCHIBALD
sp.p: And how can good come out of a lie , Helen ?

lg.l: Perhaps it wouldn ’ t be a lie always . Don ’ t you remember the Happy
Hypocrite ? Love can work many miracles .
You mean — you think I might become really what
Claude thinks me ?

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: You might try .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: D ’ you know that I should never have a moment ’ s peace ?

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: If you love Claude really , that mightn ’ t be too great a price to pay for his happiness .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Vehemently .Oh , it ’ s all very well for you to talk , but you don ’ t know what this sense of shame is . It ’ s killing me . And the degradation of being loved for what you ’ re not . And you want me never to escape from it . Oh , you ’ re right . It would be a fiendish punishment .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: It ’ s the only return you can make for all the love that Claude has given you .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Taking up the thought .For his wonderful kindness , and all these years of thought and loving tenderness .

div.stage: For a moment GRACE stares in front of her as the words sink in .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: Grace , it ’ s I who ask you now to be brave .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: With a great sigh .I seem to see the chance of a greater sacrifice than anything I ’ d ever dreamt of . I wonder .... I believe there ’ s a chance ....With a sudden start .Oh ! listen .

div.stage: She has heard CLAUDE come in . There is a sound of voices in the hall .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: That ’ s settled it . It ’ s too late now to do anything .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: What is it ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Claude ’ s just come in . I heard him speaking to Moore . He ’ s been given the letter .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: D ’ you mean to say ....Some part of the facts dawns upon her and she bursts out violently .Oh , it ’ s not that the human race are wicked that I mind , or that they ’ re weak — you can give them backbone ; but what I can ’ t get over is that they are such blooming fools .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Will you leave me , both of you ? Claude had better find me alone .

sp.speaker: MISS VERNON
sp.p: To ARCHIBALD , after a glance at GRACE .Come .

div.stage: They go out . GRACE is horribly frightened . She stands quite still , pulling her handkerchief about . CLAUDE comes in . He has a letter in his hand . He flings it on a table . GRACE sees with a start that it is unopened .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Forcing herself to seem natural .Is the inquest over ?

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Sinking dejectedly into a chair .They brought in a verdict of suicide while of unsound mind .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: That was what you expected , wasn ’ t it ?

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: You must be thankful it ’ s finished and done with .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: With an effort .The jury passed a vote of censure on me .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Claude !

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Oh , if you ’ d only heard the questions they asked me ! There were reporters there , so it ’ ll be in the papers and you can read for yourself . They made me appear a perfect brute .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I ’ m sure it wasn ’ t as bad as you fancy .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: You see , I hadn ’ t a chance of defending myself . I wasn ’ t going to make excuses to a parcel of Dissenting shopkeepers . It made me look as if I hadn ’ t a leg to stand on .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: After all , what can it matter what a dozen yokels think of you ?

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: And afterwards when I came out — they had the inquest in that big room upstairs at the Insoley Arms — there was a crowd outside , people I ’ d known all my life , I suppose they ’ d been taking the opportunity to have a good soak , and they hissed me as I passed .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Didn ’ t you say that you were going to abolish the rule ?

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Of course I ’ m going to abolish the rule . Hang it all , it ’ s caused wretchedness enough .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I wish you ’ d had an opportunity of telling them .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Rather shamefacedly .The coroner asked me what I was going to do about it . I couldn ’ t knuckle under then with all those people round me . I simply couldn ’ t , Grace . I was obliged to say that I meant to be master in my own house , and I didn ’ t propose to let anyone dictate to me .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Putting her hand on his shoulder .I ’ m afraid you ’ ve been awfully worried , old man .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: It ’ s given me a bit of a knock to find out that they — they just hate me . I was rather fond of the people on the estate , and I thought they were fond of me . When they ’ ve been in trouble I ’ ve done every damned thing I could to help them . When times have been bad I ’ ve not bothered much about the rents , and we ’ ve never been rich . Hang it all , I ’ ve given them all my time and my thoughts for years , and the only result is that they can ’ t stick me . They haven ’ t got any mercy if I ’ ve made a mistake . They give me no credit for good intentions .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I ’ m sure you exaggerate , Claude . You fancy they feel more bitter than they really do .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Oh , if you ’ d only seen them ! The pleasure they took in having a dig at me ! I could see the hatred on their faces . Oh , I expect Archibald is right . Our time down here is over . The only fellow they want in the country now is the Jew stockbroker with his pockets full of money .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Darling , I know that you ’ ve always acted for the best . I know how much you ’ ve done for the people on the estate . After all , it wasn ’ t for their gratitude that you did it , was it ? It was because it was your duty .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Rising .Oh , Grace , I don ’ t know what I should do without you . You ’ ve been so awfully good to me through the whole thing . I ’ m so grateful to you .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: What nonsense !

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: I was so afraid it would make a difference to you , but it hasn ’ t , has it ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Shaking her head .No .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: If I lost you , Grace , I couldn ’ t live . Without you — I can ’ t imagine life without you .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: How absurd you are , Claude .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: I ’ m talking rot , aren ’ t I ?

div.stage: He notices the letter , which he had put on the table , and picks it up . GRACE catches her breath .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Hulloa ! I forgot to open this . Moore gave it me as I came in .With surprise .It ’ s your hand-writing .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Quite naturally , holding out her hand .It ’ s nothing . I was afraid I should have gone out by the time you came in , and I wanted to remind you about the herbaceous border . It ’ s only a note .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Giving her the letter .Are you going out ?

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I was going to motor to Wells with Helen Vernon .

div.stage: As she speaks she tears the letter into little bits .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: Don ’ t leave me to-day , Grace . I want you so awfully badly .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Sinking with exhaustion into a chair .No , I won ’ t leave you ... if you want me .

div.stage: CLAUDE kneels down by her side .

sp.speaker: CLAUDE
sp.p: I always want you , Grace . You ’ re so much to me .... After all , nothing can really matter to me so long as I have you . It ’ s such a comfort to think that I can trust you . And you ’ ll never round on me . I ’ m awfully grateful for you , Grace .

div.stage: He buries his face in her lap , kissing her hands .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: In a trembling voice .I can never be such a wife to you as you deserve , Claude . But I can try . If you can believe in me always , Claude , perhaps in time I can become what you believe me .He makes a movement .No , don ’ t look at me . I want you to know that I love you with all my heart , I love you with my body , and I love you with my soul . I want to forget myself and think only of you . What does my happiness matter so long as I can make you happy ?

div.stage: She bends down and kisses his hair .
